The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of Blake’s etchings/engravings of John Flaxman’s Compositions from the Works Days and Theogony of Hesiod (1817). Both the designs and the inscribed texts are fully searchable.
The thirty-seven Hesiod plates are one of Blake’s major endeavors as a commercial etcher/engraver of designs by other artists. Flaxman began to sketch designs based on Hesiod’s poems in the early 1790s, but it was not until February 1816 that he entered into a contract with Longman & Co. to compose a series of illustrations for publication. Blake had already been commissioned to execute the plates, almost certainly on the recommendation of Flaxman, a friend of many years. The publisher began to receive proof impressions in November 1814; the project was completed by January 1817. Blake, who received very few other engraving commissions during this period, was paid 5 guineas (£5.5s.) for each plate, a total of £194.5s. Without the Hesiod project, Blake and his wife Catherine might have descended into dire poverty.
Blake executed the Hesiod illustrations in an unusual graphic style. Rather than continuous outlines, found in the engravings of Flaxman’s other classical compositions, Blake used stippled lines—that is, lines composed of dots. It is surprising to see Blake, who wrote in a letter of 1827 that "a Line is a Line in its Minutest Subdivision[s]," deploying a technique that divides lines into points. Perhaps he was responding to the character of Flaxman’s preliminary drawings, now untraced, upon which the etchings/engravings were based. If these were in soft pencil, then stippled lines would be an appropriate equivalent. It is also possible that Flaxman or his publisher directed Blake to use this style.
Flaxman’s classical compositions were influenced by, and often understood as recreations of, Greek and Etruscan vase paintings. His illustrations of Homer’s Iliad and Odyssey and of Dante’s Divine Comedy were published, or at least engraved, in 1793. They soon became famous and highly influential throughout Europe. These were followed by designs for the tragedies of Aeschylus in 1795 and Blake’s Hesiod engravings in 1817. Blake also contributed three plates to the 1805 revised publication of the Iliad illustrations; these are forthcoming in the Archive.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

desc.objtitle: COMPOSITIONS FROM THE WORKS DAYS AND THEOGONY OF HESIOD., Object 1 (Bentley 456.1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The muse presides over a musical contest between Hesiod (on the left) and the blind Homer (on the right) to determine who is the best singer of tales. The muse sits on a dais or (stone?) plinth, facing forward with her head turned to the left and slightly up. Her right leg is crossed over her left and she props her left elbow on her right knee; she may be resting her head on her left hand. She is wearing a tunic, or possibly a gown and a cloak, and a halo of stars encircles her head. The tripod prize to be awarded the contest winner sits to the left of her. At the left side of the design stands Hesiod, facing forward and to the right. Wearing a tunic with drapery falling to the left, he holds a hammer-like object in his right hand and plays a cithara that is strapped to his body. His left hand is visible through the strings of the cithara, which his fingers appear to be plucking. His head is turned to the right, towards the muse, and his mouth is open as if he is singing. At the right side of the design stands Homer, facing forward and slightly left. He also wears a tunic, but the folds of drapery leave his upper body exposed. He holds a hammer-like object in his right hand, near the cithara that is strapped to his chest. His left hand is raised with fingers poised as if about to strum the cithara's strings. His eyes appear either closed or empty to indicate his blindness. Vegetation decorates either side of the engraved words below the dais on which the muse sits. To the left are stems of grain with at least six tassels. To the right is an oak branch with a single fork, bearing leaves and acorns. A decorative sheaf of grain stems lies horizontally just above the title, above the muse's head. A pair of wings extend above and below the sheaf.

component.illusobjdesc: The muse presides over a musical contest between Hesiod (on the left) and the blind Homer (on the right) to determine who is the best singer of tales. The muse sits on a dais or (stone?) plinth, facing forward with her head turned to the left. Her right leg is crossed over her left and she props her left elbow on her right knee; she may be resting her head on her left hand. Her left index finger is extended along her temple in a pointing gesture. Her right arm is at her side, with her elbow out as if her right hand is at her waist. She is wearing a tunic, or possibly a gown and a cloak, with a belt or gathering beneath her breasts; the cloak is wrapped around her right arm and hangs in folds of drapery towards the floor. A halo of stars encircles her head. Her right foot, which seems to be wearing a sandal, is visible beneath the hem of her tunic. Her hair is long and seems to be twisted or braided or twisted above her left ear.
The muse is sitting on a dais or (stone?) plinth at the center of the design. The tripod prize for the best singer of tales sits on the dais to the left of her.

Vegetation decorates either side of the engraved words below the dais on which the muse sits. To the left are grain stems with at least six tassels. To the right is an oak branch with a single fork, bearing leaves and acorns.
A decorative sheaf of grain stems lies horizontally just above the title, above the muse's head. A pair of wings extend above and below the sheaf.

At the left side of the design stands Hesiod, facing forward and to the right. He wears a tunic with drapery falling to the left. Hesiod's right arm is at his side but bent upward at the elbow; he holds a hammer-like object in his right hand and plays a cithara that is strapped to his body with two straps or belts that extend diagonally over his right shoulder. The fingers of his left hand, visible through the hole of the cithara, appear to be plucking its strings. His head is turned to the right, towards the muse, and his mouth is open as if he is singing. He has a beard and thick curly hair.

At the right side of the design stands blind Homer, facing forward and slightly left. He wears a tunic, but the folds of drapery leave his chest and upper body exposed. His right arm is at his side with the elbow slightly bent, and he holds a hammer-like object in his right hand near the cithara that is strapped or belted to his chest. His left arm is bent upward at the elbow and his left hand is raised with fingers poised as if about to strum the cithara's strings. His eyes appear either closed or empty to indicate his blindness. He has curly hair and a beard, and appears to be balding. His left leg is positioned in front of his right, as if he is walking forward with that leg or resting his weight on his right.

lg.l: WORKS DAYS AND THEOGONY OF HESIOD.
THERE, LET ME BOAST THAT VICTOR IN THE LAY
I BORE A TRIPOD EAR'D, MY PRIZE AWAY
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown. London, Jan. 1, 1817.

objnote.p: There are two ink preliminary designs on one leaf in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Hesiod sits in profile on the left, facing right. Hunched over, he rests one elbow on his lap and gestures with his right hand. The crook of a shepherd's staff is visible above his shoulder; a shovel rests against the ground by his feet. He looks to the right where his brother Perses sits in profile facing left. Perses slumps in his seat and looks down, one hand resting on his chin. Both brothers are wrapped in cloaks that leave their feet and ankles exposed. A set of scales hangs inside a wreath, possibly made of grain stems, positioned in the space between the two brothers. Two vines or branches extend from the wreath, one on each side. The branch on the left side is oak, bearing acorns as well as leaves. The branch on the right may be holly. The seats on which the brothers sit are decorated with curling tendrils of vegetation; the leaves on the right may be ivy. More vegetation appears to the left of Perses' feet. Grass or other vegetation may cover the ground between the brothers.

component.illusobjdesc: Hesiod sits in profile on the left, facing right, with his legs bent at the knee so his feet rest on the ground. Hunched over, he seems to be resting at least his right elbow on his lap as he gestures with his right hand. His thumb and two first fingers on this hand are extended. The crook of a shepherd's staff is visible above his shoulder; the spade of a shovel rests against the ground by his feet. He is wrapped in a cloak that covers his entire upper body, including his arms, but leaves his feet and ankles exposed. He looks to the right. He has a beard and hair long enough to cover his ears, while the top of his head is bald.
The crook of a shepherd's staff is visible above Hesiod's shoulder, behind his head. A shovel rests on the ground near his feet, its blade pointing downwards.

Hesiod's brother Perses sits in profile on the right, facing left. His legs are likewise bent at the knee so his feet rest on the ground. He slumps in his seat and looks down, with the fingers of his right hand resting on his chin, or alternately, with his chin resting in his right hand. Like Hesiod, his entire body is wrapped in a cloak so that only his ankles and feet are bare. A bump on his thigh, under the cloak, suggests that his left hand may be resting there. He has wavy hair that is long enough to cover his ears.
A set of scales hangs inside a wreath, possibly made of grain stems, positioned in the space between the two brothers. The two ends of a rope, ribbon, or band dangle below the wreath.

Two vines or branches extend from the central wreath, one on each side. Each branch arches over the head of one of the brothers and then splits into two curling tendrils. The branch on the left is oak, bearing acorns and leaves. The branch on the right is holly.

The seats on which the brothers sit are decorated with curling tendrils of vegetation. Both tendrils bear leaves; the leaves of the tendril on the right are probably ivy. Another vine with leaves curls upward to the left of Perses' feet. Grass or other vegetation may cover the ground between the brothers.

lg.l: DEEP LET MY WORDS OH PERSES! GRAVEN BE
HEAR JUSTICE, AND RENOUNCE THE OPPRESSOR'S PLEA
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, Jan. 1, 1817.

objnote.p: Two drawings of an alternative version of the design, one finished in wash, were last recorded in the collection of Christopher Powney in 1976.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Pandora sits or leans on a block of stone or short pillar, facing left. Her head is bent and her hands are in her lap. She wears what appears to be a sleeveless gown, gathered at the waist and falling to obscure her feet. To the right stands Hermes, also facing left and apparently looking at Pandora. Wearing a hat (his petasus) and knee-length cloak, he holds his caduceus over Pandora's head. Athena stands at the left side of the design, facing right towards Pandora. She is dressed in a gown with folds of drapery gathered loosely at her waist and has a cloak hanging over her right shoulder; a helmet with face mask and plume is pushed back on her head. Her long curly hair is tied with a loose band below the nape of her neck and falls between two rows of decorative loops on the back of her gown. With one hand she reaches out to place a garland on Pandora's bent head.

component.illusobjdesc: Pandora sits or leans on a block of stone in the center of the design, facing left. Her legs are slightly bent. Her visible left arm lies at her side and along her lap, and her hands rest on her thigh. Her head bent, she appears to be looking down towards the ground. Her wavy hair is pulled back into a bun or chignon at the nape of her neck, although a few short pieces of hair have escaped at her temple. She is wearing a gown, apparently sleeveless although the lines for arm holes are not depicted, that gathers at the waist and falls in folds to the ground, covering her feet.
Athena is placing a garland of flowers on Pandora's bent head.
Pandora sits or leans on a block of stone or a short pillar.

Hermes stands at the right side of the design, facing left and apparently looking at Pandora. He is wearing a hat (his petasus) and a cloak that comes to just above his knees. His feet and legs are bare, with his left foot positioned slightly forward of his right. His left arm is not shown, apparently beneath the cloak. His right forearm and hand are depicted held about shoulder height; with this hand he is holding his caduceus over Pandora's bent head. He has short, rather curly hair.
Hermes holds his caduceus, with its intertwined serpents, over Pandora's bent head.

Athena stands at the left side of the design, facing right towards Pandora. She is dressed in a gown with draping fabric gathered loosely at her waist and has a cloak hanging over her right shoulder and falling in folds of drapery almost to her feet. A helmet with face mask and plume is pushed back on her head. Her long curly hair is tied with a loose band below the nape of her neck and falls between two rows of decorative loops on the back of her gown. Her right arm is raised and extended; with this hand she reaches out to place a garland on Pandora's bent head. What may be the crook of her bent left elbow is visible behind her back. Her bare right foot shows beneath the hem of her gown.

lg.l: BADE HERMES LAST ENDUE WITH CRAFT REFINED.
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: A variant pen and pencil preliminary drawing is in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings. A preliminary sketch in the collection of University College, London, is close to the engraved design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Persuasion, at the far right, the three Graces, and the Hours (on the left) adorn Pandora. Pandora stands in a gently contrapposto position near the middle of the design, facing forward but looking left. Her right arm is extended while her left arm is bent, her left hand resting on the shoulder of the Grace to her right. She already wears a gown or tunic that fastens at her shoulders and falls in folds of drapery to her feet; the Graces are depicted in the process of dressing Pandora in a cloak or additional layer of fabric. One of the Graces stands just to the left of Pandora, facing right and leaning backward slightly, her head tilted up and back. Her right arm is bent at her waist, the fingers of her right arm holding the edge of a piece of cloth or a cloak under Pandora's right arm. This Grace is nude from the waist up; folds of transparent drapery fall from her waist to the floor, wrapping around her legs and feet. Another Grace kneels to the right of Pandora, at her feet. This Grace faces left and looks slightly down. Her left arm is extended down towards the hem of Pandora's gown. She is nude but for the folds of cloth that wrap her legs. The third Grace stands behind and to the right of the kneeling Grace, bending slightly forward towards Pandora, who rests a hand on this Grace's shoulder. Her arms are bent towards Pandora and she is holding the edge of a piece of cloth or cloak under Pandora's left arm, helping the leftmost Grade to wrap this cloth around Pandora's back. This Grace is entirely nude; her curly hair is in a bun and she may be wearing a headband. On the floor to the left of the leftmost Grace sits an ornamented box with its lid open to reveal jewelry chains or strings of beads or jewels spilling out. Above and to the left of this box hover the three Hours, facing right. The leftmost Hour is in front of the others, hovering with knees bent and bent right arm extended towards Pandora, her fingers loosely holding a sprig of vegetation with at least one flower bud. The middle Hour hovers slightly to her right, her right arm extended behind the Hours and her left bent upward, her hand at her chest. She holds a sprig of vegetation, possibly with flowers, in each hand. The rightmost Hour is depicted behind and to the right of the other two. She turns her head to the left to look away from Pandora and holds her extended arms spread wide, one reaching behind the Hours and one before them. She also holds a sprig of vegetation, perhaps with flowers, in each hand. Persuasion stands to the right of the design at a little distance from Pandora and the Graces. She faces left, with her left arm bent around her waist and her right arm bent upward, her right hand at her neck. Her hair is pulled back, apparently in a bun, and she wears a headband. Her bent head is covered with a transparent hood or wrap. She wears a cloak wrapped over her shoulders and arms that falls to about knee height, revealing a floor-length gown beneath.

component.illusobjdesc: Pandora stands near the middle of the design, facing forward but looking left. Her right arm is extended and held out from her body at 45 degrees, while her left arm is bent, her left hand resting on the shoulder of the Grace to her right. She stands in a gently contrapposto position, with her weight resting on her right leg, her right hip out, and her left leg slightly bent. The Graces are depicted in the process of dressing Pandora in a cloak or additional layer of fabric. She already wears a gown or tunic that fastens at her shoulders and falls in folds of drapery to her feet; it is open to reveal her left leg from hip to ankle. Pooling fabric at the floor may be intended to suggest her right foot. Pandora's hair is swept up into a bun and she wears a double headband.

One of the Graces stands just to the left of Pandora, facing right and leaning backward slightly, her head tilted up and back as if she is gazing up at the taller figure of Pandora. Her right arm is bent at her waist, the fingers of her right arm holding the edge of a piece of cloth or a cloak under Pandora's right arm. Her left hand, fingers bent and apart, is visible over Pandora's shoulder. This Grace is nude from the waist up, although Pandora's right arm covers her breasts. Folds of transparent drapery fall from her waist to the floor, wrapping around her legs and feet. She stands with her left leg bent slightly. Her hair is short or drawn back. Another Grace kneels to the right of Pandora, at her feet. This Grace faces left and looks slightly down. Her right arm is bent at the elbow, which is visible behind her back; she holds her right palm facing toward the viewer. Her left arm is extended down towards the hem of Pandora's gown. The fingers of both hands are slightly spread. She is nude but for the folds of cloth that wrap her legs. The muscles of her abdomen are visible in profile. On the cloth across her lap lies a decorative element, which may be a strand of jewelry, such as a necklace or bracelet. Her hair is swept back into a bun and wrapped in a band. The third Grace stands behind and to the right of the kneeling Grace, bending slightly forward towards Pandora, who rests a hand on this Grace's shoulder. Her visible left leg is bent, her foot on tiptoe. The Grace's arms are bent towards Pandora and she is holding the edge of a piece of cloth or cloak under Pandora's left arm, helping the leftmost Grade to wrap this cloth around Pandora's back. She is looking down, her head bent. This Grace is entirely nude; her curly hair is in a bun and she may be wearing a headband. All three Graces' feet are bare. Folds of cloth lie at the feet of the two right Graces.

Persuasion stands to the right of the design at a little distance from Pandora and the Graces. She faces left, with her left arm bent around her waist and her right arm bent upward, her right hand at her neck. Her right index finger is extended. Her hair is pulled back, apparently in a bun, and she wears a headband. Her bent head is covered with a transparent hood or wrap. She wears a cloak wrapped over her shoulders and arms that falls to about knee height, revealing a floor-length gown beneath. The front of her gown seems to be decorated with folds of drapery falling from below her cloak to the floor. One shoe is visible beneath the hem of her gown.

On the floor to the left of the leftmost Grace sits an ornamented box with its lid open to reveal jewelry chains or strings of beads or jewels, possibly necklaces or bracelets, spilling out. The side of the footed box is decorated with vine-like swirls.

Above and to the left of the ornamented box hover the three Hours, facing right. The leftmost Hour is in front of the others, hovering with knees bent and bent right arm extended towards Pandora, her fingers loosely holding a sprig of vegetation with at least one flower bud. Her bent left elbow is visible behind her back. She is wearing a semi-transparent gown that wraps over her left shoulder and extends below her feet. Her left knee and right leg and foot is visible in front of the gown. A ribbon cinches her waist with a bow. The middle Hour hovers slightly to her right, her right arm extended behind the Hours and her left bent upward, her hand at her chest. She holds a sprig of vegetation, possibly with flowers, in each hand. She wears a gown that fastens at her shoulder and covers her legs and feet completely. The rightmost Hour is depicted behind the other two. She turns her head to the left to look away from Pandora and holds her extended arms spread wide, one reaching behind the Hours and one before them. She also holds a sprig of vegetation, perhaps with flowers, in each hand. She is wearing a long gown as well, cinched at the waist. The two leftmost Graces have their hair in buns; the hairstyle of the third suggests her hair may be in a bun as well. The two rightmost Graces are wearing headbands.

lg.l: ADORED PERSUASION AND THE GRACES YOUNG
HER SLENDER LIMBS WITH GOLDEN JEWELS HUNG.
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

desc.objtitle: PANDORA SHEWN TO THE GODS.Pandora Shown to the Gods, Object 5 (Bentley 456.5)

objnote.p: A preliminary drawing in pen and pencil is in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings. Two very different sketches in the collection of University College, London, may picture the same event.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Hephaestus brings Pandora to the Olympian gods and goddesses, including Poseidon, Eos, Hermes, Zeus, Hera, and two other goddesses. Hephaestus is striding leftward into the scene at the right side of the design, his bent right leg in front of him, his bare left leg extended behind. Pandora walks leftward next to Hephaestus, in front of and to the right of him. Poseidon sits semi-reclining at the bottom center of the plate. Eos stands in her chariot pulled by four horses just to Poseidon's left. A star hovers over her head, emitting beams of light. Lines suggesting waves begin at the left side of the design, extend below the horses pulling Eos's chariot to just to the left of Poseidon, and continue from the right side of Poseidon's drapery to the right side of the design. Hermes sits above the heads of the horses pulling Eos's chariot, twisting rightward at the waist to lean into Zeus, at the right. Zeus and then Hera are next in line, seated and facing forward and leaning on one elbow. Zeus's left arm is resting on Hera's lap, while her right arm lies over his shoulders. Her left arm rests on the lap of the goddess seated to the right. This goddess and another goddess sit with entwined hands in the upper right corner of the design. The leftmost one faces to the left with her hand resting on the edge of the curved line beneath the gods and goddesses. The rightmost goddess faces forward and extends her right arm so that her right hand can rest on and loosely hold the leftmost goddess' left hand. A figure hovers or walks forward, facing forward and leaning sharply to the right, in the upper left corner. His right arm is down, slightly out from his side, and in his right hand he holds a torch with flames and/or smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: Hephaestus brings Pandora to the Olympian gods and goddesses. He is striding leftward into the scene at the right side of the design, his bent right leg in front of him, his bare left leg extended behind him. He bends slightly forward, his head slightly bent. He wears a hat and a one-shouldered tunic that leaves his lower legs bare. He is bearded and has long hair. He holds his bent right arm in front of his body, the fingers of his right hand perhaps touching Pandora's right arm. His left hand is visible behind Pandora's back, to her right. Pandora walks leftward next to Hephaestus, in front of and to the right of him. Dressed in a sleeveless gown gathered at a high waist, Pandora's hair is swept up in a bun and she is wearing a crown or headband. Her bent left arm is at her side, her left hand held in front of her. Her head is bent and she seems to be holding the folds of her gown in her left hand. Semi-transparent(?) layers of fabric wind around her left upper arm. Her right upper arm is bent upward at her side, the fingers of her right hand resting gently on her right shoulder. Only her left leg is visible up to the mid-thigh, perhaps through transparent folds of her dress, stepping forward. Both Hephaestus's and Pandora's feet are bare.

Eos stands in her chariot, drawn by four horses, just to the left of Poseidon. Her torso, visible from the hips up, faces forward but her head is turned to look right. Her right arm is at her side, bent at the waist, and she is holding the reins to her horses in her right hand. Her left arm is bent upward, her left hand at her shoulder, where it holds a scarf or length of cloth that billows behind her. The other end of the cloth drapes over her right upper arm. Eos is wearing a tunic-like gown, gathered at the shoulders and cinched at her waist with a belt that is tied in a bow. Her hair is pulled back in a bun and she seems to be wearing flowers on her head. A star hovers over her head, emitting beams of light.
Eos stands in her chariot drawn by four horses. Decorative scrollwork in the form of acanthus leaves covers the front of the chariot.

Four horses, facing left, draw Eos's chariot. The foremost horse rears up, its head back. Its prancing front legs are visible to just below the knees, where lines suggesting waves obscure the rest of the horse's legs and its body below its belly. The chest, neck, and head of the next horse are visible to the left of the first horse; it holds its head similarly up and back. The head and mane of a third horse are visible above and to the left of the second horse, while the nose and mouth of a fourth horse are visible below the head of the second horse. Three of the horses have visible open mouths, each with tongue and upper teeth showing. Three of them also have visible manes cropped close and standing up from their necks. All four horses are wearing bridles; at least two have visible reins leading to Eos's hand.

Lines suggesting waves begin at the left side of the design, extend below the horse pulling Eos's chariot to Poseidon's right side, and continue from the right side of Poseidon's drapery to the right side of the design.

Poseidon is sitting in a semi-reclined position at the bottom center of the plate. He leans on his right elbow, his torso facing forward and his head turned to the right. His left leg is bent upward and his right leg rests along the ground, knee bent towards the viewer. Both legs lie to the right. His left arm is extended, slightly bent, and his left hand rests on his left knee. He has a curly beard and shoulder-length hair, and he is wearing a circlet or headband, visible over his hair at the back of his head. He is nude but folds of drapery wrap around and cover the lower half of his body.

Hermes sits above the heads of the horses pulling Eos's chariot. His lower body faces forward and slightly left, but he twists rightward at the waist so that his torso is turned slightly to the right and his head is seen in profile looking right. He sits with his bent legs drawn slightly up and leans right, towards Zeus, who sits next to him. Holding his caduceus in his right hand, he props his extended right arm on his right knee. The caduceus with its intertwined serpents leans rightward echoing Hermes's position. The short-haired god wears a hat and loose trousers, and has a cloak or other cloth draped over his lap. He is nude from the waist up.

Zeus (left) and Hera (right) sit near the top center of the design. Both face forward with bodies turned slightly to the left. Zeus's right arm is at his side, bent and with his upper arm resting on his lap. His bent left arm is held out from his side, and his upper arm is resting on the lap of Hera, who is seated above him and to the right. His left hand dangles down from her knee, with his first finger loosely pointing. His legs are bent and his calves may be crossed, left leg over right. He has a beard and long hair. His upper body is nude, but a cloak or other cloth drapes over his lap covering his lower body. Hera sits with her right arm extended horizontally, resting along Zeus's shoulders. Her right hand is visible lying on his right shoulder. She holds her left arm out to the right at 45 degrees. Her lower arm is wrapped in a cloth and resting on the lap of another goddess seated above and to the right. Hera is wearing a sleeveless gown that is belted at the waist. Her hair is drawn back and she has a tiara or crown on her head and hoop earrings in her ears. She seems to have an additional cloak or cloth draped over her bent legs. Her head may be turned slightly to the left.

Two additional goddesses sit with entwined hands in the upper right corner of the design. The leftmost one faces left and slightly forward, with her head bent and her bent left arm down by her side. Her left hand rests on the edge of the curving line below. Her legs are bent and Hera rests her left arm on this goddess' lap. She is dressed in a gown with a high gathered waist that may be belted. Her hair may be short, or it may be pulled back into a bun, and she is wearing a crown or tiara. The rightmost goddess faces forward and slightly left. Her left arm is at her side, bent with her upper arm lying on her lap. Her right arm is slightly bent, extended down so that her right hand can rest on and loosely hold the leftmost goddess' left hand. Her legs are bent and one knee may be crossed over the other. She is wearing a sleeveless gown with a high waist that may be belted. Her hair is drawn back into a bun and she wears a tiara or crown. Her head is bent forward slightly. They each may have an additional cloak or cloth draped over their legs.

A male figure, possibly a messenger, hovers facing forward and leaning sharply to the right, in the upper left corner. His right arm is down, slightly out from his side, and in his right hand he holds a torch with flame and/or smoke. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent upward, with his open palm facing out, fingers spread. His legs are together, with his left leg slightly forward. He is nude with visible genitals and short hair.

lg.l: ON MEN AND GODS IN THAT SAME MOMENT SEIZED
THE RAVISHMENT OF WONDER WHEN THEY SAW.
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: There are variant preliminary drawings in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, and in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Hermes carries Pandora to her future husband, Epimetheus, at Zeus's command. Hermes is depicted flying in a semi-prone position across the design: his separated, bent legs extend to the right while his torso stretches obliquely leftward, twisted to face away from the viewer. One wing is visible at each ankle; he wears a hat, the petasus, with a third visible wing attached. He is holding Pandora in his bent, upraised arms. She is also facing to the left, reclining slightly in Hermes's arms. Her left arm is at her side, lying along Hermes's right upper arm. Her legs are bent, her knees propped against Hermes's left arm, her feet dangling in front of his chest. Pandora's head is bent down but her eyes are raised slightly to look forward. Her hair is swept up and surmounted by a crown or tiara. Both Hermes and Pandora are nude, but wrapped in lengths of cloth that wind around Pandora's legs and left hand, wrap around Hermes's waist and hips and over his upper arm, and billow behind them. The cloth seems semi-transparent over Pandora's left hand, ankles and right foot.

component.illusobjdesc: Hermes carries Pandora to her future husband, Epimetheus, at Zeus's command. Hermes is depicted flying in a semi-prone position across the design; his separated, bent legs extend to the right while his torso stretches obliquely leftward, twisted to face away from the viewer. His right leg is bent downward, while his left leg, slightly bent, extends behind him. His head is turned to face slightly forward and to the left. One wing is visible at each ankle; he wears a hat, the petasus with a third wing over his short hair. He is holding Pandora in his bent, upraised arms. Only his right upper arm and elbow, drawn back and held upward to his right, are visible beneath Pandora. He holds his bent left arm out to the left. He is nude except for a short cloth that wraps around his waist and hips and extends slightly behind.

Pandora reclines slightly in Hermes's arms, facing to the left. Her right upper arm is bent upward with softly closed fist resting on her right breast. This hand may be holding onto the fabric that drapes over her right shoulder. Her left arm is at her side, lying along Hermes's right upper arm. Her left hand is wrapped in a cloth that folds over Hermes's arm and extends slightly behind. This cloth seems semi-transparent over her left hand and right foot, but opaque where it covers Hermes's arm. Her legs are bent, her knees propped against Hermes's left arm, her feet dangling in front of his chest. Pandora's head is down but her eyes are raised to look forward. Her hair is swept up, possibly into a bun, and surmounted by a crown or tiara. She is nude, but wrapped in lengths of cloth that wind around her legs and billow behind her.

lg.l: HE BADE HEAVEN'S MESSENGER CONVEY THRO' AIR
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: There are variant preliminary sketches in the collection of University College, London, and a German private collection.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Epimetheus, the brother of Prometheus, accepts Pandora from Hermes. Epimetheus is shown at the right side of the plate, facing left in a seated position, leaning back and drawing his left arm drawn back. He is nude except for a cloak or length of cloth that drapes over his right shoulder and falls into his lap and covers the seat on which he sits. He extends his right hand to Pandora, who steps forward facing right, her own left hand held out towards Epimetheus'. She looks down towards their hands, her head bent, and holds her right arm at her side. She is wearing a long gown, gathered at a high waist, that seems to be sleeveless although no arm seams are depicted. Her hair is in a bun and she wears the same crown as in the previous design. Hermes is standing just to the left of Pandora, stepping forward with his left leg. His left hand is visible just above her left shoulder, where it holds the staff of his caduceus (with its intertwined serpents), which points downward towards Epimetheus' hand. Hermes holds his open right hand at Pandora's waist, his bent arm at his side. He appears to be nude except for a short cloak and his hat, which is resting behind his shoulder. A large covered jar rests on the ground between Pandora's and Epimetheus' feet.

component.illusobjdesc: Epimetheus, the brother of Prometheus, accepts Pandora from Hermes. Epimetheus is shown at the right side of the plate, facing left in a seated position, leaning back and drawing his left arm back to rest that elbow behind him. He extends his open right hand to Pandora, who steps forward before him. Both of his legs are bent, with his right foot on tiptoe beneath his seat and his left foot stretched out to rest away from his body. He is nude, except for a cloak or length of cloth that drapes over his right shoulder and falls into his lap and covers the seat on which he sits. He has short, rather curly hair.

Pandora is facing right and stepping forward with her right foot, her left hand held out toward Epimetheus'. She looks down towards their hands, her head bent, and holds her right arm at her side. She is wearing a long gown, gathered at a high waist, that seems to be sleeveless although no arm seams are depicted. Her hair is in a bun and she wears the same crown as in the previous design. Her right foot is visible beneath the hem of her gown; the sweep of the gown also seems to indicate her left heel behind her.

Hermes is facing right and standing just to the left of Pandora, stepping forward with his left leg; his right foot is on tiptoe. His left hand is visible just above her left shoulder, where it holds the staff of his caduceus (with its intertwined serpents), which points downward towards Epimetheus' hand. Hermes holds his open right hand at Pandora's waist, palm vertical, his bent arm at his side. He bends slightly forward over her, his head bent down. He appears to be nude except for a short cloak and his hat, which is resting behind his shoulder. Unlike in the previous design, no wings are visible on his heels or hat. He has short, curly hair.
A large covered jar rests on the ground between Pandora's and Epimetheus' feet.

lg.l: Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: A pencil drawing, the size of the engraving and perhaps copied after it by someone other than Flaxman, is in the Fogg Art Museum, Cambridge, Massachusetts.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Epimetheus retreats in horror as Pandora holds open the jar's lid and personified "ills" (see the engraved text at the base of the design) escape and begin to scatter. He lunges away from the jar towards the left of the design, his legs spread and his torso facing forward with most of his weight seemingly resting on his right arm and bent right leg. His left leg extends behind him to the right, to the base of the jar. His right arm is extended, hand braced against a step or stone on the ground. His left arm is bent up, with his hand at his forehead. His head is twisted sharply up and to the right; his eyes are wide and his mouth is open. He may be crying out in fear. Pandora kneels at the right side of the jar, her legs folded beneath her, holding the jar's lid propped open with both hands. Head bent slightly back and mouth open, she faces left towards Epimetheus and the "ills." Four "ills" spring in a line from the jar in poses of flight; a fifth "ill" is shown between Epimetheus' legs, and a sixth appears to the left of his right arm. Hope remains seated within the (now transparent?) jar, holding a flower in her hand.

component.illusobjdesc: Epimetheus retreats in horror as Pandora holds open the jar's lid and personified "ills" (see the engraving at the base of the design) escape and begin to scatter. He lunges away from the jar towards the left of the design, his legs spread and his torso facing forward with most of his weight seemingly resting on his right arm and bent right leg. His left leg extends behind him to the right, to the base of the jar. His right arm is extended, hand braced against a step or stone on the ground. His right hand forms a fist. His left arm is bent up, with his hand at his forehead. His head is twisted sharply up and to the right; his eyes are wide and his mouth is open. He may be crying out in fear. He is nude except for a cloth that drapes over his right leg and groin and falls to the ground behind him. He has short, curly hair.

Pandora kneels at the right side of the jar, her legs folded beneath her, holding the jar's lid propped open with both hands. Her arms, both slightly bent, are extended in front of her. Head bent slightly back and mouth open, she faces left towards Epimetheus and the "ills." She is dressed in a sleeveless gown that covers her feet and a cloak that drapes over at least her left shoulder. Her hair is tied in an extended bun at the back of her head and she is wearing a crown or tiara.

Four "ills" (see the engraved text at the base of the design) spring in a line from the mouth of the open jar. The ill closest to the mouth of the jar resembles a skeleton with prominent ribs; it leaps leftward with right leg bent and left leg and arm extended, its right arm bent and right hand at its head. Its head is bent back. The ill just above and to the left appears human-like, perhaps male. Its legs are bent backward and its visible bent left arm held close at its side. Facing left, it bends forward and thrusts its chin forward, head bent back. The ill just above looks human-like, perhaps female. Its arms are spread and raised at 135 degrees; its right leg is bent double and its left extended. With body facing forward, it turns its head to look right, mouth open. A fourth ill, facing left, appears behind this female ill, with one forearm and hand showing to the right of her waist, and head and shoulders showing to the left. A fifth ill, bald, appears in downward-facing flight between Epimetheus' legs. Stretched long as if in a line from top right corner to bottom left, this ill flies left and down. It holds its right arm extended vertically (relative to its body) and its left arm bent and drawn back. Its head is bent back and up. One leg is extended behind it and the other is bent up towards its chest. Of indeterminate gender, this ill is probably a human-like male. A sixth ill in horizontal flight appears to the left of Epimetheus' right arm. Its arms are extended and spread wide at about 135 degrees, its right hand holding a scroll-like object, or perhaps a spear or bone, and its left arm disappearing after the elbow. This ill's thin limbs, knobby left shoulder, and facial features suggest a skeleton. It is bald. Though it appears to be flying left, its head is turned to look right. All of the ills are nude. Lines above the female ill's forehead suggest hair, while the other three in this line are bald.
Pandora holds the lid of the jar in front of her propped open with both hands. The jar rests on a rectangular base or plinth.
The male on the left rest his right hand on a step or stone.

Hope remains seated within the (now transparent?) jar. She appears to be wearing a gown, her legs bent and her left hand resting on her knees. This arm is bent and at her side. She is holding a flower, or possibly a branch or sprig of indeterminate vegetation. She faces left, with her head turned slightly up. Her hair in a bun, her head is bent back.

lg.l: SHE LIFTS THE LID._SHE SCATTERS ILLS IN AIR.
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: The British Museum, Department of Prints and drawings, has a slight pencil sketch of the figure group, two related pencil sketches on the verso of a drawing for Object 12, and a proof of the engraving lacking all letters except the Greek word ("god") within the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two women and a baby represent the Golden Age. Both women are seated. The woman on the left kneels, her legs folded beneath her, and faces to the right. She is handing the baby to the woman on the right, who sits facing left with her left arm bent. The baby faces right and leans forward towards the woman on the right, reaching out his right hand to touch this woman's neck. All three are nude, though the woman on the left has a cloth draped over her left shoulder. A fire burns at the top of a pillar-like altar at the right of the design. Three shafts of grain stand at the left side of the design; a vine or vines bearing leaves and clusters of grapes stretch across the top of the design, above the women's heads. Greek letters appear between the left woman's head and a cluster of grapes at the center of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The woman on the left kneels, her legs folded beneath her, and faces to the right in profile. She stretches her bent arms out to the right, giving the baby to the woman on the right. The fingers of her left hand are wrapped around the lower left leg of the child, while her right hand supports the child's chest. She is nude but has a cloth draped over her left shoulder and falling in folds to the ground beneath and behind her buttocks. Her hair is pulled into an extended bun.

The woman on the right sits in profile facing left, with her bent knees up. Her legs are crossed at the ankles and her bare feet rest on the ground in front of the other woman's knees. She bends forward, slightly hunched, left arm bent. She holds the child's torso with this hand and touches her nose and mouth to the child's forehead. Her hair may be short, or it may be long and swept into a twist behind her head. She is nude.

The baby faces right and leans forward toward the woman on the right, reaching out his right hand to touch this woman's face and neck. His left leg is bent and drawn up near his body, while his right leg, also slightly bent, is extended. His right foot rests on the thigh of the woman on the left. His eyes are raised as if he is looking at the face of the woman on the right. He is nude with short curly hair.
A fire burns at the top of a pillar-like altar at the right of the design. Several small (wood?) logs are visible beneath the flames. Clouds of smoke billow upwards.
Three shafts of grain with tassels stand at the left side of the design.
An inscription in Greek, "ΘΕΟΣ" (god) appears within the design, right of the head of the woman on the left. See the textual transcription.

A vine or vines bearing leaves and clusters of grapes(?) extends across the top of the design, above the women's heads. There are grape clusters above the shafts of grain, between the child's head and the leftmost woman's head, and just to the left of the fire on the altar. The vine or vines are intertwined above the head of the woman on the right.

lg.l: LIKE GODS THEY LIVED WITH CALM UNTROUBLED MIND.
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: There is a preliminary drawing in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A women and a baby lie or half recline on the left. A wolf crouches near the center of the design, head turned up and to he left with fangs bared. A figure at the left is stretched full-length, his(?) head resting against one forearm. The woman on the right sits facing left and leaning back. The head and one arm of a child are visible resting in her lap. A winged Minister "of Good" (see the engraved text below the design) stands or strides over the figure on the left. He holds a staff and faces right towards the other woman. Four winged figures wrapped in cloaks hover or fly above the women. Three, a male and two females, face left and hover or fly from right to left in the background of the design. The fourth, a female, faces to the right and hovers over the seated woman at the right. She reaches her right hand out to touch the woman's cheek and holds the woman's right hand in her left.

component.illusobjdesc: One of the winged figures faces to the right and hovers, nearly prone, above the seated woman at the right side of the design. Her torso and lower body are extended to the left, not quite horizontally. Her legs are slightly bent. Her left foot is visible beneath the hem of the gown she wears. She holds her large feathered wings folded behind her back. A cloak wraps her upper body and trails behind her; folds of its drapery fall over her right arm, which she reaches out towards the seated woman. The winged figure touches the seated woman's cheek with her right hand and holds the woman's right hand in her left. Her hair is swept up into an extended bun.

The woman in the bottom lower right corner of the design sits reclining against something not pictured. Her left arm is at her side, her left hand in her lap and holding the hand of the child in her lap. She holds her right forearm up; her right hand rests in the hand of the winged figure hovering over her. Her head is back, her curly hair spread against the support at her back, but her eyes are open and seem to be looking at the winged figure above her. She seems to be wearing a sleeveless belted gown. Her lower body is covered by a cloak or blanket. The head, right shoulder, right arm, and possibly the left fingers of a child rest in her lap. This child, with long hair and at least a nude upper body, may be male or female. The child's head faces forward with eyes closed (possibly sleeping) and his or her right arm is bent where it lies on the woman's lap, his or her hand wrapped within the woman's larger one. The fingers of the left hand may be visible just above the woman's gown to the right of the child's head.

The young male(?) figure at the left is lying prone at full-length on the ground. His head is turned to face forward and rests against his right forearm. His eyes are closed and he seems to be sleeping. Both head and arm are propped on a rock or stone. His right hand is lying slightly in front of his face. He is wrapped in a cloak or blanket that covers his left arm and hand and his upper body down to below his buttocks. His nude left leg is visible lying along the ground with the top of the foot facing forward; the leg may be bent slightly forward at the knee. His hair is either short or pulled back from his face.

A winged Minister "of Good" (see the engraved text below the design) stands or strides forward and to the left, his legs spread over the woman lying on the left. His right leg is forward and on tiptoe, in front of the sleeping figure, and his left leg is extended backward and to the right, behind the sleeping figure. Though his torso faces forward, he turns his head to the right and seems to be looking down, as if towards the woman on the right. He holds a staff in his right hand, which is at his side; the staff may be resting against his right forearm. His right arm is slightly bent; his left arm is stretched out to the right at an angle between horizontal and 45 degrees. He holds his feathered, folded wings out to either side of his body. A cloak draped over his right shoulder extends behind his back to wrap around his pelvis from his left side, covering his genitals. Otherwise he is nude. His short curly hair hangs in a forelock over his forehead.

A snarling wolf crouches on the ground between the two resting figures. Facing right, it hunches over and lowers its torso, so that its front legs are nearly parallel with the ground. The wolf turns its head up and to the left, as if looking at the winged Minister striding over the woman on the left. Its mouth is open, perhaps barking or snarling and revealing upper and lower teeth and its tongue. It holds its tail between its back legs. Its ribs are visible. A rock or possibly a tuft of grass appears to the right of its front left paw.

Three winged figures, a male and two females, face left and hover or fly from right to left in the background of the design. Each figure is wrapped in a cloak covering his or her body entirely up to the neck. The figure farthest left appears to be a male with short hair, looking ahead and facing left. His lower body has not been drawn. The middle figure seems to be a female with hair drawn up into an extended bun. She also looks ahead and faces left, her cloak flying behind her. The figure farthest right also appears to be a female with long hair; though her body faces left, she turns her head to look forward. The folds of her cloak fly behind her. A ribbon, band, or fold in her cloak obscures her chin and mouth. Each figure flies or hovers in the prone position, head up, and carries his or her feathery wings behind the back.

lg.l: EARTH-WANDERING DÆMONS THEY THEIR CHARGE BEGAN,
THE MINISTERS OF GOOD, AND GUARDS OF MAN;
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A couple reclines, representing the Silver Age (see the engraved title at the top of the design). The man sits nearer to the right edge of the design and leans back, propped on his left elbow, which itself rests on a mound or pillow. He raises his right arm up at 135 degrees, holding a bowl, and tilts his head back to look upward. The man props his right foot sacrilegiously on the altar that sits at the left side of the design. He is nude and has thick hair that curls around his forehead, temples, and the nape of his neck. The woman, nude from the waist up, sits with her body facing forward and to the left, her knees bent upward. Her legs may be crossed beneath the cloak or blanket draped over her lower body, given the position of her right foot. Leaning backward slightly,she rests her bent left elbow on the man's genital area and turns her head to the right, as if to look at the man or his upraised hand. Her extended right arm is propped on her right knee. She holds a smaller bowl in her right hand. The large square altar at the left side of the design is decorated with a central design incorporating a pair of wings and what may be a stylized sheaf of wheat. Below this central design appears a scrollwork-like decorative element, perhaps the capital of a pillar. A large, tall jar or bottle with handles stands right of the man.

component.illusobjdesc: A young, muscular man sits near to the right edge of the design and leans back, propped on his left elbow, which itself rests on a mound or pillow. Though his torso faces slightly forward, his lower body extends to the left. He raises his slightly bent right arm up at 135 degrees, holding a bowl, and tilts his head back to look upward. The man's left leg is invisible behind the woman; his right leg is bent at the knee. He props his right foot sacrilegiously on the altar that sits at the left side of the design. He is nude and has thick hair that curls around his forehead, temples, and the nape of his neck.

The woman, nude from the waist up, sits with her body facing forward and to the left, her knees bent upward. Her legs may be crossed beneath the coat or blanket draped over her lower body. Her right foot is visible beneath the hem of this cloak or blanket. Leaning backward slightly, she draws her bent left arm backward and rests this elbow on the man's genital area. She turns her head to the right, head bent slightly back, as if to look at the man or his upraised hand. Her extended right arm is propped on her right knee. She holds a small bowl in her right hand. Her curly hair is styled in a bun.

The large square altar at the left side of the design is decorated with a central design incorporating a pair of wings and what may be a stylized sheaf of wheat. Below this central design appears a scrollwork-like decorative element that may be the capital of a pillar.
A large, tall jar or bottle with handles stands right of the man.

lg.l: NOR WOULD THEY SERVE THE GODS.
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: The British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings, has three preliminary drawings on two leaves (one with additional pencil sketches in the margins), three sketches on the verso of a drawing for Object 20, and several small sketches on a drawing for Object 24. A variant preliminary pencil sketch is in the Huntington Library and Art Gallery, San Marino, California. A proof of the engraving in the Morgan Library and Museum, New York, with a proof of Object 36 on the verso, lacks all letters.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design shows men attacking one another in combat, while lions and snakes enter the scene from the right. The men are nearly all dressed for combat, with seven of eight wearing helmets (some of which have crests), and at least one also wearing body armor. Many carry shields and/or weapons. Three men to the right of center face left towards their combatants at the left side of the design, who face right. Near the center of the design, one leftward facing man holding a spear lunges left, so low to the ground that he is nearly in a crouching position. His left leg is drawn forward and bent, and his right leg extended behind him to the right. Two leftward facing soldiers shown above him stand with weapons in raised arms, holding circular shields, decorated with a serpent (left) and a horse (right), and swords. A fourth man, nude, kneels on all fours facing right near the bottom right corner of the design. Two rightward facing men stand or lunge on the left side of the design with right legs bent and drawn up, left legs extended. Each wields a long-handled spear. A third rightward facing man crouches or lunges near the left edge of the design, his torso facing forward, his left arm raised and holding a shield. A fallen soldier lies limply over a mound or rock, his legs bent and his left arm extended over his head. Three leftward-facing lions lunge into the scene from the right side of the design. Above them coil two snakes.

component.illusobjdesc: Near the center of the design, one man lunges left, so low to the ground that he is nearly in a crouching position. Though his head is turned to look left, his torso faces away from the viewer. He leans slightly left, with head bent sharply back. His left leg is drawn forward and bent at the knee, and his right leg is extended behind him. Both feet are on tiptoe. His right arm is drawn back behind him and bent at the elbow; he holds the shaft of a spear with this hand. His other arm is bent at the elbow and held in front of his chest, so that his lower arm and hand are not visible. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open. He is nude with well-defined muscles, and wears a crested helmet. His chest may be pierced by the spear of the enemy combatant to the left. He holds his own long spear its with sharp arrowed point directed at the opposing men.

Just above the man lunging left near the center of the design stands his fellow soldier, also facing left. This man holds his bent right arm upward, elbow out to the left and hand above his head, grasping the handle of a downward pointing sword. He wears a fearsome expression, with eyebrows drawn, and a helmet with a crest. His large circular shield, decorated with a twisting snake, obscures his mouth and chin and the rest of his torso. The snake on the shield has its mouth open with forked tongue extended. The man's right knee is visible beneath and to the left of the shield, above the thigh of an enemy soldier. A rectangular shaped object visible between the torso and thigh of the lunging soldier in front may represent part of the left leg of this soldier behind.

Above and to the right of the lunging soldier, to the right of the soldier with the snake shield, stands another soldier. This soldier is also facing left and carrying a sword and shield. He holds his bent right arm drawn back behind him, with fist upraised and holding a sword. He is wearing a helmet with a large crest and what may be a type of visor or eye guard. His large circular shield, decorated by a running horse with its head hidden behind the other soldier's snake shield, obscures his upper body. Nothing of his lower body appears below the shield.

A nude man kneels on all fours near the bottom right corner of the design. He rests on his knees with his lower legs extending away from the viewer; his upper body bends forward and to the right. His bent arms are braced on his clenched fists, which are on the ground, and his helmetless head, with short hair, bends down so that his face is not visible. The lion immediately to the right claws the man's back and shoulder with both of its front feet.

Three leftward-facing lions lunge into the scene from the right side of the design. The foremost lion is visible from chest forward. Its two front feet, with claws visible, are on the back of the kneeling man to the left. It has its mouth open, with teeth showing and tongue extended. A thick mane circles its neck. Just to the left appears the head and some of the mane of a second lion, also with open mouth, tongue extended, and teeth showing. One bent leg, perhaps belonging to this second lion, appears beneath the forelimbs of the lion in front. The head and mane of the third lion, turned slightly away from the viewer, shows above the second lion's head. With mouth open, it shows at least one tooth and an extended tongue. Above the lions coil two serpents, each with mouth open and forked tongue visible. Their tails are not shown.

A muscular soldier at the left side of the design stands or lunges with legs spread wide, facing forward. He is straddling a fallen comrade lying beneath him. His right leg is bent and propped on a rock or mound at the bottom left corner of the design. Most of his weight seems to be resting on this leg. His left leg is extended to the right and this foot is on tiptoe. With his torso facing forward, he seems to be plunging his spear into the chest of the enemy soldier below and to the right. His bent right arm is drawn back, his hand grasping the end of his spear. His left arm is bent, elbow raised to shoulder height, hand near his chest and holding the spear near the mid-point of its handle. He turns his head to the right and bends his neck slightly downward. He wears greaves on his legs and a crested helmet fitted with what appears to be a visor that is propped up to cover his forehead. Short hair may be visible beneath the back of his helmet. Lines on his chest indicate body armor, while draping fabric around his waist and covering his genitals suggests a short tunic.
A large rock or small mound appears on the left side of the design just above the bottom margin.

Just behind and to the left of the soldier facing forward with legs spread stands his fellow soldier, also facing right. His leg position imitates the position of the soldier in front of him: his legs are spread wide, with his right leg bent and lifted, and his left leg extended to the right. His torso faces forward but his head is twisted to look to the right. His right arm is bent, with the elbow raised to shoulder height and the forearm lowered perpendicular to the ground. With this hand he is holding the shaft of a spear, the point of which is invisible behind his comrade. His left hand is visible to the left of the soldier in front of him, and is also grasping the spear. The soldier is wearing a crested helmet; lines on his torso may indicate body armor. He has a small mustache and short hair just visible at his temple and neckline, beneath his helmet.

A fallen soldier lies on his back at the lower right corner of the design, partially obscured by a mound or rock over part of which he seems to be lying. His legs are bent, knees upward. His left arm is stretched above his head; his right arm is not visible. With head bent slightly back, his face looks toward the sky, with eyes closed and mouth open slightly. He is nude except for some form of cloth draped over his pelvic area. He is also wearing a helmet. He may be dead.

A soldier crouches or strides leftward at the left side of the plate. His torso faces forward and to the left, but he turns his head sharply back and right to look upward and to the right. He leans slightly leftward. His bent left arm is up with the elbow just above the height of his shoulder. He is holding the handle of a shield, front side facing away from the viewer, with his left hand. His right hand is visible at chest height, gripping the handle of a sword. His right leg is bent at the knee and drawn up near his body, while the thigh and knee of his extended left leg is visible between the legs of two soldiers in front and to the right. He is wearing a helmet, below which curls of hair are visible. He appears to be nude and his mouth is open.

lg.l: THEY BY EACH OTHER'S HANDS INGLORIOUS FELL,
IN FREEZING DARKNESS PLUNGED, THE HOUSE OF HELL;
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme and Brown, London, Jan. 1, 1817.

desc.objtitle: MODESTY AND JUSTICE RETURNING TO HEAVEN., Object 13 (Bentley 456.13)

objnote.p: The British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings, has two slight pencil preliminary sketches, a possibly related sketch of Zeus enthroned on the verso of a drawing for Object 27, and a proof of the engraving before all letters with a proof of Object 34 on the verso.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Modesty and Justice stand or hover before Zeus, who sits in a throne-like chair at the upper left corner of the design. Modesty faces leftward and bows meekly, veiling her face with a portion of the cloak that wraps around her lower body and right arm. Her leg position, with feet crossed and dangling, suggests that she is hovering. Justice, facing away from the viewer and slightly to the left, leans backward and allows liquid to pour out of a jar or vial that she holds in her right hand, with her arm extended behind her. Hera sits in profile on the left, looking right and wearing a crown. Athena sits in the upper right corner of the design, facing forward and to the left, with her head bent down. She is wrapped in a cloak and wearing a decorated helmet with a crest. The signs of the zodiac appear in a curved banner across the design behind Zeus.

component.illusobjdesc: Zeus sits in a throne-like chair near the upper left corner of the design. He is facing right with his legs bent at the knee. The lower leg and heel of one foot is visible beneath the hem of his garment. His right arm, slightly bent, is at his side and his hand rests on the arm of the throne. He holds the end of a staff or scepter loosely with his left hand; the other end rests against his left shoulder. His head is bent slightly. He has thick shoulder-length hair and a beard with two points. Nude from the waist up, he is wearing a tunic with decorations at the hem wrapped around his lower body and draped over his left shoulder, from where it falls in folds over his lap to his knee.
Zeus sits in a throne-like chair. Relatively simple in design, its most decorative element is the pair of winged Sphinxes that support its visible arm.

Athena sits near the upper right corner of the design facing forward. Her body is turned slightly to the left and she turns her bent head to the left. Her right arm is bent to lie across her lap, while her left arm is at her side, forearm lifted and hand in front of her chest. Her legs are bent and her toes, clad in sandals, are visible beneath the hem of her garments. Her right foot is positioned back and to the side of her seat. Athena is wearing a crested helmet decorated with horses, two of which (at the top) are winged. Her hair is visible at her temple and falling in long locks at the nape of her neck. She seems to be wearing a cloak that covers her hands and arms. Decorative elements from her clothing frame her neckline.

Hera is sitting in profile facing right near the lower left corner of the design. Her visible right leg is bent and her right foot, clad in a sandal, shows beneath the hem of her clothing. She wears layers of garments, one of which has a decorative hem, that cover her body completely. The folds of her garments that hang below her foot suggest that her leg may be dangling, or resting on some form of footstool. Her right hand may be indicated by a bump under her clothing resting on her thigh. The end of a staff or scepter appears between her back and the left side of the design. She wears a tiara or crown and her hair is drawn up through it into a bun at the back of her head. The decorations on the crown include stylized acanthus and round objects that may be gems or pearls along its upper edge.

The signs of the zodiac appear in a curved banner behind Zeus and Athena. These are of course abstract representation of constellations of stars. From left to right they are two feet perhaps extending from the hem of a gown or skirt (possibly Virgo, the maiden), some rounded objects that do not clearly picture any of the signs of the zodiac, the leg and bent arm of a figure possibly holding scales (Libra), an animal crouching and facing left (an ill-formed lion of the sign Leo?), Cancer the crab with claws, a seated dog(?) facing left and with its tail clearly pictured (not corresponding to any sign of the classical zodiac), the lower body and legs of a figure (possibly one of the twins of the sign Gemini or the water bearer of the sign Aquarius).

Modesty and Justice stand or hover before Zeus. Modesty faces leftward and bows meekly, bending her head down. Her leg position, with feet crossed and dangling, suggest that she is hovering. Her left arm is at her side, elbow bent and forearm raised so that her hand is in front of her face. With this hand she is holding her cloak to shield her face from Zeus. Her right hand is visible at her waist, as if this arm is wrapped around her body. Folds of cloth or a cloak envelop her lower body, although since her legs and feet are visible through the folds, some or all of the material is transparent. The transparent material drapes over the back of her head from her right shoulder; from there it falls in front of her torso and wraps around her right arm. She holds part of this section of the cloak in front of her face like a veil. Her hair seems to be tied in a bun at the back of her head. Her crossed legs are bent at the knee. Justice stands or hovers behind and above her, closer to Zeus. She leans backward, facing away from the viewer and slightly to the left, and tilts her head back to look upward. Her bent left arm is at her side, open hand in front of her chest with palm out, fingers slightly spread. Her right arm is extended behind her, with her right hand grasping a downward-facing jar or vial out of which liquid pours. Justice's curly hair is styled in a ponytail. She is wearing a long gown, tied at the waist with a belt; her feet are not visible.

lg.l: MODESTY AND JUSTICE RETURNING TO HEAVEN.
JUSTICE AND MODESTY FROM MORTALS DRIVEN
RISE TO THE IMMORTAL FAMILY OF HEAVEN.
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, Jan. 1, 1817.

objnote.p: There is a pen and pencil preliminary drawing in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design presents a scene of conflict. A female Fury, or Erinyes to the Greeks, stands or strides leftward at the center of the design, with arms spread wide. She holds a snake in her outstretched left hand and a smoking torch with visible flames in her right. A second Fury stands or strides leftward near the left edge of the design, though she turns her head to look to the right. She brandishes a torch with flames and smoke in her upraised right hand and a snake in her left. Both Furies wear snake ornaments at their foreheads, above their wild hair. Between the Furies, towards the left of the design, two nude muscular men struggle in combat. One lies on the ground in a supine position at the feet of the other, who stands above him. The standing man uses one arm to hold his enemy down by the neck while he draws his other arm backwards, clasping a dagger. The man on the ground is propped rigidly on buttocks and left elbow, straining as he reaches upward with his extended right arm to hold the chin of his combatant. To the right of the central Fury, a third nude man leans forward and drags two women, or a woman and a child, rightward. He faces right and away from the viewer: his torso faces right and slightly forward, but his head is turned away and seen in partial profile. The female on the right, clearly adult, kneels or crawls forward on her knees, facing right and away but turning her head so that her face is visible in two-thirds profile. She embraces the female child(?) on the left with her extended left arm. The child wraps her own bent right arm around the woman's extended left arm, and leans her head forward to rest her forehead on it. The man grasps the child's partially undone hair at the nape of her neck and holds the woman's right hand as he pulls them away. At the right edge of the design sits or crouches a bearded old man dressed in a tunic, with at least one knee bent and drawn up and his head bent down low. His right arm is at his side, slightly bent, with the knuckles resting on the ground, while the fingers of his left hand touch his forehead. Flames appear near the upper right corner of the design, and billowing smoke fills the corner.

component.illusobjdesc: One of the female Furies, or Erinyes to the Greeks, stands or strides leftward near the left edge of the design. Her bent right leg is forward as if she is taking a step, while her left leg is not visible. Though her torso faces forward and to the left, she turns her head to look to the right. Her arms are spread wide, her left extended and raised at 135 degrees, her right raised and bent over her head. She holds a flaming torch with a plume of smoke in her right hand and a coiling snake, mouth open and forked tongue extended, in her left. Her mouth is open and her hair, standing on end, spreads in wild abandon around her head. Two snake heads with open mouths form an ornament above her forehead that mimics the snake-like quality of her hair. She is wearing a short gown, tied at the waist with a belt, with a fold of fabric flying behind her like a cape or cloak.

Two muscular men struggle in combat at the left side of the design. One of the men stands or lunges above the other, leaning over his combatant who lies on the ground. The standing man seems to have most of his weight on his left leg, which is bent and drawn forward, while his right leg extends behind him. His right foot rests on tiptoe. Facing left and leaning forward, his torso is turned away from the viewer, but he twists his head left to look down at the man below. His right arm is drawn back and extended, and he holds a dagger or knife in this hand with the point down towards his combatant. His left arm is extended downward and braced against the other man; he is holding his enemy's throat with his left hand. His chin is grasped in the right hand of his combatant. He is nude and has short hair.

Two muscular men struggle in combat at the left side of the design. One of the men lies on the ground in a supine position at the feet of the other. This man on the ground rests on his buttocks and his lower left arm, which is propped on his elbow. His straining back arches and his legs are spread around the leg of his enemy, with the bent left leg drawn up in the air above him, and the bent right leg resting on his right foot. He reaches upward with his straight right arm and holds the chin of his enemy above. His torso is positioned facing up and away from the viewer, but his head is bent back sharply, so that the viewer sees his face upside down. His enemy's hand is on his neck. He is nude and has short hair.

Near the middle of the design stands or strides one of the female Furies, or Erinyes to the Greeks, facing left. Her bent right leg is forward, her left extended behind her on tiptoe. Her torso faces left but twists away from the viewer slightly. She holds her left arm straight out in front of her, holding a curling snake with tongue extended in this hand. Her right arm is extended behind her; in this hand she holds a flaming torch with smoke swelling to the right. Her head is bent back and her mouth is open. Her snake-like long hair flies behind her head, to the right. Two snake heads with open mouths form an ornament above her forehead that mimics the snake-like quality of her hair. She is wearing a short sleeveless gown that ends mid-thigh and is circled with a belt. A cloak swirls around her, billowing over her right shoulder and visible to her left and right.

An old man sits or crouches in the lower right corner of the design, facing right. His visible right leg is bent upward, and he bends forward in a hunched position, his head down and nearly touching his knee. His right arm is at his side, slightly bent, with the knuckles of his hand resting on the ground. The fingers of his left hand touch his forehead; this hand may be resting on his knee(s). He has short hair and a beard, and his mouth is slightly open. He is wearing a tunic or a tunic and cloak that wraps his lower body and drapes over his left shoulder. His upper body is partially bared, and his right foot is visible beneath the hem of his garment.

A nude man to the right of the Fury at the center of the design drags two women, or a woman and a female child, rightward. The man faces right and away from the viewer: his torso faces right and slightly forward, but his head is turned away and seen in partial profile. One bent leg is forward. The other, extended backward, is visible only behind the knee between the two women. His right arm is extended behind him; this hand holds on to the hair at the nape of the neck of the woman on the left. His left arm wraps around his body, and this hand holds the hand of the woman on the right. His short hair seems rippled by wind as he leans forward slightly.

Two women, or a woman and a female child, below and to the right of the Fury in the middle of the design are being dragged rightward by a man. The foremost woman, on the right, is kneeling or crawling rightward on her knees. Her left knee is in front of the right, which is extended behind her. Her torso faces away from the viewer, but her head is turned so that her face is visible in three-quarters profile. Her mouth is open. Her right arm is at her side, bent upward; the man grasps her right hand in his. Her left arm, drawn back, wraps around the back of the child(?) on the left, whose own arm is wrapped around the forearm of the woman on the right. She is dressed in a long sleeveless gown, belted at the waist. Her right heel is visible, at least in outline, beneath this gown. She seems to have long hair gathered behind her head. The female child(?) on the left faces right and leans her head down to rest it on the rightmost woman's forearm, around which the child has wrapped her bent right arm. Her eyes are closed. The man is grasping the child's partially undone long hair behind the nape of her neck. She is wearing a sleeveless gown, and her lower body position beneath it suggests that her right leg is forward and her left leg extended behind her.
Flames appear in the upper right corner of the design, above the old man. Smoke billows throughout this corner.

lg.l: AND LAY THEIR MUTUAL CITIES DESOLATE
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, Jan. 1, 1817.

objnote.p: There is a pen and pencil preliminary drawing in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.
