illustration.illusobjdesc: Justice, holding her scales in her left hand, departs from an unjust world. She is suspended in midair as if floating upward and to the right. Although her torso is turned to the right and slightly forward, her head is twisted back and away so that her face is only slightly visible. Her right arm is extended at 45 degrees behind her, palm facing away from the viewer. She is dressed in a belted gown and cloak. Three men stand at the left side of the design, thrusting Justice away from them (see the engraved caption). The man furthest to the right is positioned a little in front of the other two, standing facing right with his torso facing away from the viewer and his head, turned to look right, seen in profile. He holds his bent left arm at his side and his extended right arm out nearly horizontally, palm up and facing to the right. He is wearing a tunic or cloak. The man furthest left, with curly hair and beard, stands facing forward, with his head turned to look rightward. His feet are clad in sandals and positioned shoulder-width apart. His right hand grasps the head of a long staff or walking stick. Dressed in a cloak, he holds his extended left arm out horizontally, palm out and facing right. The third man stands behind the other two, who obscure him slightly. This man faces forward but turns his head to the right so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His legs are bare, but he seems to be wearing a cloak or tunic. The "gates" mentioned in the engraved text below the design are represented by two perpendicular lines in the upper left corner.

component.illusobjdesc: Justice departs from an unjust world, suspended in midair as if floating upward and to the right. Although her torso is turned to the right and slightly forward, her head is twisted back and away so that her face is only very slightly visible. Her left arm is at her side and bent upward, and she is holding her scales in her left hand. Her right arm is extended at 45 degrees behind her, palm facing away from the viewer. Her feet dangle with toes downward, left foot crossed behind the right. She is wearing a gown cinched below her bust with a belt and a cloak that wraps her lower body and over her left shoulder. Her head may be adorned with a circlet, or perhaps her hair is arranged in a ring around her head.

Three men stand at the left side of the design. The man furthest to the right is positioned a little in front of the other two. He stands with his torso facing away from the viewer and his head, seen in profile, turned to look right. He holds his bent left arm at his side and his extended right arm out nearly horizontally, palm up and facing to the right. He is casting Justice from him. His stance is wide, with his left leg straight and his right leg out and slightly bent. He is wearing a tunic or cloak wrapped around his upper body; it extends to his knees and leaves his lower legs and right shoulder bare. His hair is short with a longer forelock.

Three men stand at the left side of the design. The man furthest to the left stands facing forward, with his head turned to look rightward towards Justice. His feet are clad in sandals and positioned shoulder-width apart. His right hand grasps the head of a long staff or walking stick. He holds his extended left arm out horizontally, palm out and facing right. He is casting Justice away from the group. He has curly hair and a curly beard, and his mouth is open; he may be speaking. He is wearing a knee-length cloak.

Three men stand at the left side of the design, one behind and slightly obscured by the other two. This man faces forward, but turns his head to the right so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His legs are bare, but folds of cloth visible over his left shoulder and between the other two men's legs suggest that he may be wearing a tunic or cloak. His mouth is open; he may be speaking. He has short curly hair.
The "gates" mentioned in the engraved text below the design are represented by two perpendicular lines in the upper left corner.

lg.l: THEY THRUST PALE JUSTICE FROM THEIR HAUGHTY GATES.
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, Jan. 1, 1817.

objnote.p: There is a slight pen and pencil preliminary sketch in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings. Two drawings of "The Angel of Pestilence" in the collection of University College, London, may be related. A sketch similar to those at University College is in the Huntington Library and Art Gallery, San Marino, California.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Justice with her scales in hand hovers or flies leftward near the center of the design, her body nearly horizontal. She bends backwards slightly at the waist, but looks down with downcast eyes. Her right arm is extended horizontally behind her, and she holds her scales with this hand. She holds her bent left arm in front of her, with her left hand at her forehead. She is wearing a long gown and a cloak. A female spirit hovers or flies leftward to the left of Justice. Her bent right arm is out in front of her; her left arm is straight by her side. Each hand holds a downward-facing jar or vial from which she pours streams of liquid representing "famine and pestilence" (see the engraved text below the design). She has long hair and wears a sleeveless belted gown. A personification of Zeus's "wrath" hovers or flies leftward near the upper right corner of the design. This androgynous figure has its head up and its face turned away from the viewer, visible only slightly. The figure has long hair streaming behind its back, and hovers or flies with its straight left arm extended horizontally behind it and its bent right arm held out horizontally in front of its face, elbow forward. The figure is enveloped in a billowing cloak. A man lies on his back on the ground at the lower right corner of the design, his head near the corner. With head bent back, mouth open, and eyes closed, he may be dying or dead (the engraved caption below the design reads in part, "in heaps they die"). Another, younger man sprawls backwards near the bottom of the design. He seems to be resting on his right knee and toes, left heel, and right arm, though the woman to the left may be helping to prop him up with her shoulder and knee. His torso faces forward and up; his head is back and his face looks up to the sky. His mouth is open; he may be dead or dying (see engraved caption). He has short hair and is nude except for a fold of cloth draped between his legs. A woman kneels facing forward to the left of this man. She is bending forward so far that the tops of her shoulders are facing out towards the viewer. She is wearing a sleeveless gown with buttons or clasps visible over her right shoulder. Her left knee, bent upward, seems to be partially supporting the upper left arm of the man sprawling to the right. Her head is down, perhaps resting on top of this same man's upper arm, and her face is not visible. Her hair is gathered into a bun at the nape of her neck. Just to the right of the man sprawling backwards, a woman lies embracing him. Kneeling, her body faces left and rests against his left side. Her visible left eye is open, but the pinprick pupil gives the impression that it stares blankly. Her loose-limbed, limp position suggests that she may be dead or dying (see the engraved caption). Two additional figures are partially visible lying near the bottom left corner of the design. The head of one appears lying in the corner, tilted back and up so that the face is shown upside-down, eyes closed. The second figure is lying in a supine position a little above the head in the corner, with head near the edge of the design and body extending rightward at a downward sloping angle. This figure's eyes are closed and mouth open. Both figures may be dead or dying (again, see the engraved caption).

component.illusobjdesc: A female spirit hovers or flies leftward in a prone position, her body horizontal, in the upper left corner of the design. Her bent right arm is out in front of her; her left arm is straight by her side. Each hand holds a downward-facing jar or vial from which she pours streams of liquid representing "famine and pestilence" (see engraved text below the design). She turns her head so that her face, looking down, is visible to the viewer. Her long hair, parted in the center, streams behind her. She wears a sleeveless gown that is belted at the waist. Her feet are not visible.

Justice hovers or flies leftward in a prone position near the center of the design, her body nearly horizontal. She bends backwards slightly at the waist, but looks down with downcast eyes. Her right arm is extended horizontally behind her, and she holds her scales with this hand. She holds her bent left arm in front of her. Her left hand is at her forehead; she may be resting her head on this hand. She is wearing a long gown that is at least partially transparent because her lower left leg and foot are visible beneath the folds of drapery that extend beyond her feet. A cloak wraps around her lower torso and over her left shoulder. Her hair is drawn behind her head in a bun.

A personification of Zeus's "wrath" hovers or flies leftward in a prone position near the upper right corner of the design. This androgynous figure, with its head up and its face turned away from the viewer and visible only slightly, may be male or female. The figure has long hair streaming behind its back, and hovers or flies with its straight left arm extended horizontally behind it and its bent right arm held out horizontally in front of its face, elbow forward. Both hands are in fists. Its mouth is open. Enveloped in a cloak that wraps over its right shoulder and billows behind it, the figure has only one visible foot, the left, showing between the folds of drapery. The position of the fabric suggests the bent left leg, with knee pointing down and slightly out.

A man lies on his back on the ground at the lower right corner of the design, his head near the corner. His legs are together with knees bent upward. His left arm is at his side, resting on the ground. He is nude except for a fold of drapery that covers his lower torso and pelvis, and wraps around his lower left arm and hand. This cloth may be of a piece with the cloth (cloak or gown) that partially covers the woman lying near the man's legs, obscuring his feet. He has short hair and a beard; since both seem pale, he may be old. His head is bent back and his mouth is open. His eyes are closed, and he may be dying or dead (the engraved caption below the design reads in part, "in heaps they die").

A man sprawls backwards near the bottom of the design. He seems to be resting on his right knee and toes, left heel, and right arm, though the woman to the left may be helping to prop him up with her shoulder and knee. His right leg is bent and his right foot is on tiptoe, while his left is extended and his left foot rests on its heel. His right arm is slightly bent and braced against the ground, hand in a fist. This arm may also be resting against or supported by the left knee of the woman to the left. His left hand is visible resting on the back and shoulder of a woman to the right, who leans against his chest. His torso faces forward and up; his head is back and his face looks up to the sky. His mouth is open. He may be dead or dying (the engraved caption below the design reads in part, "in heaps they die"). He has short hair and is nude except for a fold of cloth draped between his legs and over his right upper thigh and pelvis. This cloth seems to overlap with or join the cloth covering the woman to the right and the old man lying in the right corner of the design.

A woman kneels facing forward to the left of the man sprawling backwards near the bottom of the design. She is bending forward so far that the tops of her shoulders are facing out toward the viewer. She is wearing a sleeveless gown with buttons or clasps visible over her right shoulder. The folds of her gown cover her feet entirely and seem to join or be of a piece with the cloth that drapes over the other figures at the bottom of the design. The shape of her skirt suggests that her left knee is bent upward, with this foot resting flat on the ground; this knee seems to be partially supporting the upper left arm of the man sprawling to the right. Her right leg is bent under her hips, with this knee on the ground. Her head is down and may be resting on top of this man's same arm. Her face is not visible. Her hair is gathered into a bun at the nape of her neck. Her bent right arm is down and may be helping to support her weight; her right hand rests on and partially holds the man's right fist. The fingers of her left hand are shown resting on the left side of the man's neck. She may be mourning for the dead or dying figures around her.

Just to the right of the man sprawling backwards near the bottom of the design a woman lies embracing him. Kneeling, her body faces left and rests against his left side. Her extended left arm lies across his pelvis, her hand dropping limply from her wrist. Her head faces left and out towards the viewer, but her face is half-hidden against the man's chest. Her hair seems to be drawn back into a low bun. Her visible left eye is open, but the pinprick pupil gives the impression that it stares blankly. From the waist down she is wrapped in a cloth or gown that covers her body entirely and extends below her feet, and seems to join or be of a piece with the drapery covering the old man lying to the right and the sprawling man to the left. Her loose-limbed, limp position suggests that she may be dead or dying (the engraved caption below the design reads in part, "in heaps they die").

Two figures are partially visible lying near the bottom left corner of the design. Only the head of one appears, lying in the corner. This person's head is tilted back and up, so that the face is shown upside-down, eyes closed. Short hair falling backwards onto the ground suggests that this head belongs to a male. The second figure is lying in a supine position a little above the head in the corner, with head near the edge of the design and body extending rightward at a downward sloping angle. Long loose hair suggests that this figure is a woman. Her head faces up, and her face is shown in profile with eyes closed and mouth open. She seems to be dressed in a gown that covers the only other visible part of her body, which appears between the kneeling woman and the sprawling man. A line below her head suggests that she lies against a small hill or stone. Both figures may be dead or dying (the engraved caption below the design reads in part, "in heaps they die").

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three family groups populate the lower half of the design. The central group consists of a man and a woman kneeling and facing one another. Each adult has a child on his or her lap; the children embrace and kiss one another. At the right side of the design stands or sits a man facing left and playing Pan pipes. He is resting against, and perhaps sitting in, a crook of the grapevine to the right. Just to the left of the musician, a woman kneels nursing a child at her knees. She faces left but bends forward in a somewhat hunched position, her head down. Her short-haired child faces away from the viewer, half standing with knees slightly bent, and half resting against his or her mother's legs. The child twists towards the mother to suckle. Another family grouping, including a man, a woman, and two or perhaps three children, sits at the left side of the design near the lower corner. The man sits cross-legged facing forward, though his left leg may be bent with knee raised upward. His right arm is wrapped around a standing child to his left, and his left hand appears at the back of a child sitting on his lap. The standing child faces right, with left leg slightly in front of its right leg, and visible right arm bent upward. Its hand is at its mouth. The other child sits on the man's lap with its body facing left; it turns its head to look out toward the viewer. The woman sits to the right of the man, facing away from the viewer but leaning slightly left and turning her head to look down and left towards the children, so that her face is visible in partial profile, seen from behind. She lightly embraces the child sitting on the man's lap, her left arm raised and bent around this child's upper body. A round shape visible on her lap may be the head of a third child. All of the children are nude, as is the man in the central grouping and the woman at the right. The other adults are partially clothed in fabric wrapped around their lower bodies. Three female spirits hover above the family groupings. Each faces left but twists rightward so that her head looks right. The spirit hovering over the family group sitting at the left side of the design extends her left arm out behind her at 45 degrees, loosely holding a cluster of grapes in this hand. She holds her bent right arm across her torso, close to her body. The middle female spirit hovers above and to the left of the family group sitting in the middle of the design. She holds her slightly bent right arm extended out in front of her at about 135 degrees. Her bent left arm is drawn back and raised so that her hand is at head level. She holds flowers or leaves in both hands. The third female spirit hovers above the kneeling woman at the right side of the design. Her chin is tilted slightly up and she seems to be gazing upward. Her left arm is drawn back and extended behind her, and she is loosely holding a flower and some grapes in this hand. She holds her right arm, slightly bent, extended horizontally out in front of her. All three spirits wear long gowns or skirts and shirts. A large grape vine rooted in the lower right corner grows up the right side of the design, where it supports the musician, and then curves leftward, extending across the top of the design. It sprouts large leaves and grape clusters, as well as flowers(?) and curling branches, filling up the spaces left between the figures. Sheaves of wheat lying on the ground appear between and behind the family groups at the right side of the design. A pair of scales hangs from the grape vine at the top of the design, near the center, in between two of the female spirits. The object in the lower left corner may be a sickle.

The child leans slightly forward and kisses the child sitting on the woman's lap. Its right arm is bent and its hand holds the elbow of this other child, who sits facing left and hunches slightly, extending its own bent left arm to touch the rightward facing child's head. The woman holds the leftward facing child sitting on her lap, with her bent left arm under the child's arm. Her right arm is raised in front of her torso with her palm facing outward. The man and both children are nude and have short hair. The woman's hair is drawn back into a bun; she is nude except for a cloak or cloth wrapped around her lower body.

At the right side of the design stands or sits a man facing left and playing Pan pipes. He is resting against, and perhaps sitting in, a crook of the grapevine to the right. His bent left leg is crossed over his straight right leg, with his left toes touching the ground. He bends his head slightly and holds his bent arms out in front of his body, using the fingers of both hands to play his double pipes. He is nude except for a cloak or tunic draped around his waist and falling in folds over the vine. He has short, rather curly hair.

Just to the left of the musician at the right side of the design kneels a woman nursing a child at her knees. She faces left but bends forward in a somewhat hunched position, her head down. Her weight is resting on her toes and bent knees. Her bent left arm is at her side, and she uses her left hand to guide her breast to her child's mouth. This short-haired child faces away from the viewer, half standing with knees slightly bent, and half resting against his or her mother's legs. He or she twists towards the mother and suckles at her breast; the child's one visible (right) arm is slightly bent. Both child and mother are nude. The mother's right hand appears at the child's back. The woman's hair is drawn back into a bun at the nape of her neck.

At the left side of the design, near the lower corner, sits a family grouping including a man, a woman, and two children. The man sits cross-legged facing forward, his lower body turned slightly to the right. His left leg may be bent with knee raised upward. He looks out toward the viewer. His right arm is wrapped around a standing child to his left, and his left hand appears at the back of the child sitting on his lap. He has short hair, and appears to be nude except for a tunic or cloth wrapped around his lower body. The standing child is nude and has short hair, and may be male or female. This child faces right, with its left leg slightly in front of its right, and its visible right arm bent upward. The child's right hand is at its mouth. Her legs extend away from the viewer but may be bent. She lightly embraces the child sitting on the man's lap, her left arm raised and bent around this child's upper body. Her left hand may be resting on this sitting child's right shoulder, and her chin may be resting against the child's head. Her right arm is bent at her side, and may be lying on her lap. She is nude except for a cloak or other cloth wrapped around her waist and covering her lower body. Her hair is drawn up into a bun. A round shape visible on her lap may be the head of a third child.

One of the female spirits hovers above the family group sitting at the left side of the design. Her lower body faces left, but she twists rightward so that her torso faces forward and her head, bent down, faces right. Her face is bent so low that it nearly touches her left shoulder. Her left arm is extended out behind her at 45 degrees, and she loosely holds a cluster of grapes in this hand. She holds her bent right arm across her torso, close to her body. Her bent left arm is drawn back and raised so that her hand is at head level; in this hand she holds a flower. Her hair is drawn back through a net or headband, and she is wearing a long sleeveless gown under a cloak that wraps around her right shoulder and flutters behind her.

One of the female spirits hovers above the kneeling woman at the right side of the design. Like the other two spirits, her lower body faces left, but she twists rightward so that her torso faces slightly forward and her head faces right. Her chin is tilted slightly up and she seems to be gazing upward. Her left arm is drawn back and extended behind her, and she is loosely holding a flower and some grapes in this hand. She holds her right arm, slightly bent, extended horizontally out in front of her with the fingers on this hand in a graceful position. Her hair is drawn back into a bun at the nape of her neck, and she is wearing a long gown or possibly a skirt and shirt with only one sleeve. The folds of this fabric float around her.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Pleiades, represented as the seven daughters of Atlas for whom they are named, rise into the night sky in an arc within a belt of stars, which may also be intended to represent the Pleiades in constellation form. Thirteen stars appear below the daughters, in the lower left corner of the design. Twenty-two more stars appear to the right of the uppermost Pleiades, completing the belt. The lowermost Pleiad faces away from the viewer and hides her face; she may be Merope, who is ashamed to show her face because she married a mortal. Although she is rising with her sisters, her bent right leg is etended and her right foot is still flat on the ground (or at least on the lower border of the design). Her left leg is bent and drawn upward so that the bottom of her left foot is visible. Her right arm is bent upwards at her side, with her hand at her right shoulder. Her bent left arm is raised at 135 degrees. She may be leaning against the leg of the Pleiad just above her, and resting her upper arm on this Pleiad's upper thigh or embracing her. Her hair is wrapped in two headbands and drawn into a bun at the back of her head. The Pleiad just above and to the left of Merope faces forward and to the right. Her head is tilted back and to the right and she seems to be looking upwards. Her right arm is at her side, bent slightly, and she touches Merope's back with the fingers of this hand. Her left hand rests on the shoulder of the figure just above her. Although her lower body is swathed in drapery, her right leg is visible beneath the folds, embracing Merope's upper body. Her hair is drawn back to the base of her neck, where short pieces escape from her coiffure. The third Pleiad from the bottom faces forward and to the right, but bends her head down and to the left. She stretches her slightly bent right arm across her body; the Pleiad to the right is holding her hand. Her left arm and lower body are mostly not visible, although the thighs of her bent legs, swathed in fabric, appear to the left of the arm of the Pleiad to the left. Her sleek head and the braid or twist above her left ear suggests that her hair is pulled back. Near the top of the arc of the Pleiades, directly above Merope, one of the sisters rises in a supine position, her body nearly horizontal. Her lower body, visible from knee to waist, faces up, but she twists to her right at the waist so that her torso faces away from the viewer. She turns her head even further to the right to look down, so that the right side of her face is visible in partial profile. Her left arm, slightly bent, is at her side, with fingers spread. Her right arm, bent upward, is drawn slightly back and this hand is at her shoulder. Her hair is drawn back into a bun-like coiffure and she wears a headband. Just to the right of this sister are two more sisters who seem to be supine. The uppermost one faces up, with upraised eyes. Only her face, and possibly one hand, are visible. The lower one turns her head to look down towards the ground. Her shoulder is visible to the right of the Pleiad to her left. Her sleek head and the braid or twist above her right ear suggest that her hair is drawn back. To the left of these sisters is another whose body (visible only from the waist up) is nearly horizontal. She faces forward but turns her head slightly to her right, up towards the top of the design. Her right arm is bent upward at her side, and her hand, which is in front of her breast, is holding the hand of the Pleiad to the left. Her left arm may be extended, with her left hand holding the hand of one of the sisters to the right. Like several of her sisters, her sleek head and the braid or twist above her left ear suggest that her hair is drawn back. Her mouth is partly open. All of the Pleiades are nude except for drapery that swaths their lower bodies, connecting the sisters. Two reapers harvest grain near the bottom right corner of the design. Dressed in minimal clothing, they face to the right and away from the viewer, bending to wield their sickles. Thickly tasseled, the grain rises densely from the right edge and grows two-thirds of the way across the bottom of the design.
