illustration.illusobjdesc: A prosperous farmer stands near the center of the design, looking right and leaning forward on his plow. His left leg is in front of his right. His arms are crossed and resting on his plow. His left hand holds the cloak or cloth that wraps around his torso and buttocks; part of this cloth drapes over his plow and falls in folds towards the floor. He has short hair and is nude except for the cloth. Two oxen lie on the ground near the feet of the farmer. The one nearest the left corner of the design lies facing forward and to the right. Its head is up and turned forward and to the left. The second one is seen in profile and lies facing right, its head resting on the ground. At the lower right corner of the design is an altar, shown as a large pillar-like block on a step or plinth. A fire atop the altar billows smoke upward and to the right. A flock of seven birds rises upward from above the altar towards the upper right corner. They may be intended to represent a good augury. In the upper left corner, Zeus sits facing right with a goddess (perhaps Hera) before him. He holds his staff in his right hand, and raises his bent left arm to embrace the goddess. He has long curly hair and a beard, and is dressed in robes or a cloak with a stripe decorating the hem. The goddess faces forward and to the left, leaning her folded arms on Zeus's lap. Her right arm is bent upward, and her right hand is under her chin. She is wrapped in a cloak or other fabric with a stripe decorating the hem, which winds around her right arm and over each shoulder. Her lower body is hidden. The scales of Justice hang over the head of the goddess. Apollo sits facing left in the upper right corner of the design. He is seated on a folded cloth or cloak, with a decorative vine-lined hem, that drapes down from his seat (not pictured). Both legs are bent and his right leg is crossed over his left. He leans slightly on his cithara, which is tucked under his right arm. His right hand is visible resting on top of the cithara, near his chin. His head is down slightly and he may be resting his chin on this hand. His left arm is down, but bent and drawn back slightly, and his hand is touching or holding a fold of the cloth mentioned above. He is nude except for his sandals, and has curly short hair or longer hair pulled back behind his head.

component.illusobjdesc: A prosperous farmer stands near the center of the design, looking right and leaning forward on his plow. His left leg is in front of his right. His arms are crossed and resting on his plow. His left arm is visible from mid-forearm to hand and is held out in front on him, resting on the top of his plow. His left hand holds the cloak or cloth that wraps around his torso and buttocks; part of this cloth drapes over his plow and falls in folds towards the floor. His right arm is bent upward and rests on top of the left, and his right hand is near his chin. He has short hair and is nude except for the cloth.

Two oxen lie on the ground near the feet of the farmer leaning on his plow. The one nearest the left corner of the design lies facing forward and to the right. Its head is up and turned forward and to the left. The second one is seen in profile and lies facing right, its head resting on the ground.
At the lower right corner of the design is an altar, shown as a large pillar-like block (of stone?) on a step or plinth. A fire atop the altar billows smoke upward and to the right.
A flock of seven birds rises upward from above the altar towards the upper right corner. They may be intended to represent a good augury.

In the upper left corner, Zeus sits facing right with a goddess (perhaps Hera) before him. Zeus sits with his right arm drawn back slightly and bent, as if resting on the arm of a chair or similar support (not pictured). He holds his staff in his right hand with his pointing forefinger lying along the shaft. His bent left arm is raised to embrace the goddess, and three fingers of his left hand are shown on her right shoulder. He has curly long hair and a beard, and is dressed in robes or a cloak with a stripe decorating the hem; folds of fabric drape over his right shoulder onto his lap and fall over the side of his arm support. The goddess faces forward and to the left, leaning her folded arms on Zeus's lap. Her right arm is bent upward, elbow on Zeus's lap. Her right hand is under her chin, with her forefinger pointing. Her chin may be resting on this hand. Her left arm is bent, with her forearm resting on Zeus's lap. She is wrapped in a cloak or other fabric with a stripe decorating the hem, which winds around her right arm and over each shoulder. Her lower body is hidden.
The scales of Justice hang above the head of the goddess (perhaps Hera).

Apollo sits facing left in the upper right corner of the design. He is seated on a folded cloak or cloth, with a decorative vine-lined hem with leaves, that drapes down from his seat (not pictured). Both legs are bent and his right leg is crossed over his left. He leans slightly on his cithara, which is tucked under his right arm. His right hand is visible resting on top of the cithara, near his chin. His head is down slightly and he may be resting his chin on this hand. His left arm is down, but bent and drawn back slightly, and his hand is touching or holding a fold of the cloth mentioned above. He is nude except for his elaborately strapped sandals, and has curly short hair or longer hair pulled back behind his head.

lg.l: HE TO WHOSE NOTE THE AUGURIES ARE GIVEN
NO RITE TRANSGRESS'D, AND VOID OF BLAME TO HEAVEN.
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, Jan. 1, 1817.The period at the end of the imprint printed very lightly in this copy.

objnote.p: There are two preliminary drawings in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Hesiod, represented in pastoral garb, sits on the ground near the center of the plate facing right. He is reclining against the legs of the muse sitting above him, and wearing a tunic or other cloth that wraps around his pelvis and thighs and drapes over his left arm. His legs are stretched out to the right and his slightly bent left leg is crossed over his right. His staff, possibly a shepherd's crook, is propped between his legs and resting on his left shoulder. Both hands rest on this staff. The muse above him leans over him. She sits facing right, but turns her torso away from the viewer, leaning forward with her head down and her right elbow resting on her lap. She holds her right lower arm up, gesticulating with her first finger pointed. Her left arm is bent and drawn back, shown from shoulder to lower forearm. The bottom of a lyre or cithara is pictured to the left of her lower back, as if it rests against her left hip. She is dressed in a long gown, belted at the waist. A cloak or other cloth wraps loosely around her pelvis. The toes of her bare right foot are visible beneath the hem of her gown. Her hair is drawn back into a bun and a band wraps twice around her head. A dog sits near Hesiod's feet, in the lower right corner of the design. Its body faces right, but it turns its head to look left. Two sheep and one ram graze in the background on the right side of the design, facing left above the dog. Two altars to Zeus flank the scene. A bowl atop a tripod with each leg composed of two crisscrossed members surmounts the altar on the left. A single line in an arc (broken by the top edge of the design) separates the scene from simple cosmological elements appearing in the upper corners. In the upper left corner, a rising or setting sun emitting beams of light peeks over the edge of the arc. A crescent moon appears in the upper right corner.

component.illusobjdesc: Hesiod, represented in pastoral garb, sits on the ground near the center of the plate facing right. He is reclining against the legs of the muse sitting above him, wearing a tunic or other cloth that wraps around his pelvis and thighs and drapes over his left arm. His legs are stretched out to the right and his slightly bent left leg is crossed over his right. His staff, possibly a shepherd's crook, is propped between his legs and resting on his left shoulder. His slightly bent right arm is at his side and his right hand is loosely holding the staff. This arm may be resting along his lap. His left hand is also resting on the staff, just above the right; his fabric-draped left arm is bent and at his side. He leans his head back and looks upward. He has chin-length hair, and is nude except for the cloth.
A dog sits near Hesiod's feet, in the lower right corner of the design. Its body faces right, but it turns its head to look left.

Two sheep and one ram graze in the background on the right side of the design, above the dog. The foremost is the ram, identified by his horn, who bends his head and opens his mouth to eat the grass depicted under his nose. He faces left. The sheep to the left of the ram also bends to eat blades of grass shown between her feet. She faces left but turns her head slightly forward. The cloven hoof of her front left foot is clearly shown. The second sheep is above and to the right of the ram and holds her head up, facing left.
Two pillar-like altars to Zeus flank the scene. A bowl atop a tripod with each leg composed of two crisscrossed members surmounts the altar on the left.

A muse sits above Hesiod and leans over him. She faces right, but turns her torso away from the the viewer, leaning forward with her head down and her right elbow resting on her lap. She holds her right lower arm up, gesticulating with her first finger pointing. Her left arm is bent and drawn back, shown from behind from shoulder to lower forearm. The bottom of a lyre or cithara is pictured to the left of her lower back, as if it rests against her left hip. She is dressed in a long gown, belted at the waist. A cloak or other cloth wraps loosely around her pelvis. The toes of her bare right foot are visible beneath the hem of her gown. Her hair is drawn back into a bun and a band wraps twice around her head. She might be Erato, the muse of lyric poetry whose emblem is the cithara.

A single line in an arc (broken by the top of the design) separates the scene from simple cosmological elements appearing in the upper corners. In the upper left corner, a rising or setting sun emitting beams of light peeks over the edge of the arc. A crescent moon appears in the upper right corner.

lg.l: Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, Jan. 1, 1817.

objnote.p: There are two pen and pencil preliminary drawings in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings. A pencil drawing of the seven muses on the left in the Princeton University Art Gallery, Princeton, New Jersey, may be a copy of the engraving by someone other than Flaxman.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Nine muses dominate the design. At the right side of the design, one of the muses steps forward to present Hesiod with a leafy laurel bough, emblem of victory. Facing right, she is seen in profile walking with her straight right leg forward. She is wearing a long gown, belted at the waist, with a cloak over her right shoulder. Her hair is drawn back into a ponytail. Hesiod faces left, leaning, half-sitting, against a support (pictured at most by a line right of his left fist) with his right leg crossed over his left, facing left and bending slightly forward. His straight left arm is at his side. His left hand, in a fist, is resting on the support near his buttocks. He holds his right forearm out horizontally and loosely holds the end of the laurel bough between his palm and thumb, with his first two fingers extended as if pointing. He is wearing a short cloak, draped over his left shoulder and falling to rest on his upper thighs. His hair is short and slightly curly, and he is nude except for the cloak. One of the muses sits facing forward at the right side of the design, to the right of Hesiod. Her legs are bent and her left leg is crossed over her right. She turns her torso slightly to the left and her right arm is bent upward. Her head is bent and turned left, and she may be resting her head on her right hand. She holds a cane or staff shaped like a shepherd's crook across her lap. She is wearing a long gown, belted at the waist with a band and attached or decorated at the left shoulder with three visible buttons. Her hair is drawn back into a low bun and her head is circled with a crown of leaves. A cloak or other form of cloth drapes across her lap, on the opposite diagonal from the cane. Another muse sits above and to the right of Hesiod, where she is partly hidden by the muse below. The higher muse faces right and slightly forward, but turns her head to look forward and to the left. She is wearing a shirt or gown with long sleeves and a keyhole neckline. Her hair is drawn back over her ears, and she may be wearing a wide headband or other head covering. Her lower body is mostly hidden by Hesiod's shoulder and the other muse. Just to the left of the muse handing the laurel bough to Hesiod stand two other muses shoulder to shoulder. The muse on the left faces right, wrapped in a cloak that covers her body from neck to mid-calf and falls in folds of drapery behind her. The muse to the right faces right and slightly forward. She looks forward and to the right, her face shown in three-quarters profile. The fingers of her right hand are visible on the shoulder of the muse standing to the left. A cithara is half-visible to the right of the muse's skirt where her knee would be. She is wearing a loosely-belted gown and a cloak over her upper body. The hair of both muses is drawn back. A sixth muse sits facing right and seen in profile at the left side of the design. She leans forward and hunches slightly, holding a scepter or rod and with a cithara behind it. Her visible right leg is bent and her right foot rests flat on the floor. She is wearing a skirt or gown that falls to the floor and covers half her right foot. Over this she wears a gown or long tunic that falls down from her shoulder to cover much of her right arm and is belted at the waist. Her hair is arranged in an elaborate coiffure that includes one or two buns. Above the cithara sits a seventh muse with her lower body facing left. She twists to turn her torso forward and her head to the right. Her head is slightly bent, and her hair drawn back into a bun at the back of her head. Her right arm is bent at her side and her forearm lies on her lap. Her right hand is holding an open book that is also resting on her lap. Her left arm is bent and her elbow may be resting on a hidden support. Her forearm is bent upward and her left hand is at her chin, which may be resting on this hand. She is wearing a sleeveless gown and has a cloak or other cloth draped over her lower right arm. In the upper left corner a muse kneels at the feet of her sister, leaning on her lap. Her lower body faces left, but she twists her torso forward and to the right. Her right arm is at her side, bent upward, and her right hand is in a fist resting on her sister's knee. Her left arm is bent and raised so that her forearm rests horizontally along her sister's thigh. She holds her right wrist with her left hand. Her legs are bent and tucked underneath her. Her head is bent and the braid or twist over her right ear suggests that her hair is long and pulled back behind her head. She is wearing a long gown with buttons on the right shoulder. To the left sits another muse who faces left and sits leaning on a sculpted bust of Zeus, the father of all nine of the muses. Her lower body faces left and slightly forward, but she turns her head to look forward and to the right. Her legs are bent and the bust of Zeus rests on her lap. The bust, with a beard and long hair, faces forward and to the left. It may be wearing a helmet or hat. The muse's left arm is at her side, bent upward, and her left hand rests on the top of the bust. She is wearing a sleeveless gown. Her hair is drawn back behind her ears and held with a headband, and braids or curls hang down on either side of her face.

component.illusobjdesc: At the right side of the design, one of the muses steps forward to present Hesiod with a leafy laurel bough, emblem of victory. Facing right, she is seen in profile walking with her straight right leg forward. Her left foot, on tiptoe or the ball of her foot, is visible beneath the hem of her gown. Her right arm is bent and at her side, with her forearm out horizontally and her hand holding the bough with open fingers. Her left forearm is held up in front of her and she holds the bough loosely between the thumb and palm of this open hand as well. She is wearing a long gown, belted at the waist, with a cloak over her right shoulder. Her hair is drawn back into a ponytail.

At the right side of the plate, Hesiod receives a laurel bough from a muse. He is leaning, half-sitting, against a support (pictured at most by a line right of his left fist) with his right leg crossed over his left, facing left and bending slightly forward. Both legs are straight. His straight left arm is at his side. His left hand, in a fist, is resting on the same support near his buttocks. He holds his right forearm out horizontally and loosely holds the end of the laurel bough between his palm and thumb, with his first two fingers extended as if pointing. He is wearing a short cloak, draped over his left shoulder and falling to rest on his upper thighs. His hair is short and slightly curly, and he is nude except for his cloak.

One of the muses sits facing forward at the right side of the design, to the right of Hesiod. Her legs are bent and her left leg is crossed over her right. She turns her torso slightly to the left and her left arm is bent upward. Her right forearm is raised vertically and her right hand is at her mouth, with the first two fingers extended and the next two loosely closed. Her head is bent and turned left so that her face is seen in profile, and she may be resting her head on her right hand. A cane or staff shaped like a shepherd's crook lies diagonally across her lap, propped against her upper left arm, with its curved handle up. Her left arm is bent and extended across her lap parallel to the cane, and she loosely holds it near the bottom with her left hand, her first two fingers lying extended along its shaft. She is wearing a long gown, belted at the waist with a band and attached or decorated at the left shoulder with three visible buttons. Her hair is drawn back into a low bun and her head is circled with a crown of leaves. Her feet seem encased in some form of covering, perhaps simple shoes. A cloak or other cloth drapes across her lap, on the opposite diagonal from the cane. Lines beneath her left foot may represent the ground.

One of the muses sits above and to the right of Hesiod, where she is partly hidden by another muse below her. The higher muse faces right and slightly forward, but turns her head to look forward and to the left. Her visible bent right arm is at her side, and her lower arm rests on her lap. A cloak or other cloth drapes over this lower arm and over her lap. The cloth, partially transparent, may extend up over her chest. She is wearing a shirt or gown with long sleeves and a keyhole neckline. Her hair is drawn back over her ears, and she may be wearing a wide headband or other head covering. Her lower body is mostly hidden by Hesiod's shoulder and the other muse.

Two muses stand shoulder to shoulder just to the left of the muse handing the laurel bough to Hesiod. The muse on the left stands facing right, wrapped in a cloak that covers her body from neck to mid-calf and falls in folds of drapery behind her. Her left hand is visible above the cloak, resting on her chest near her collarbone. The shape of her cloak suggests that her right arm is bent and drawn slightly backward. Below the cloak, the bottom of a skirt or gown falls to the floor. One of her feet, clad in a sandal, appears beneath the hem of her gown. Her head is bent slightly and her hair is drawn back into a bun; a curl surmounts her forehead.

Two muses stand shoulder to shoulder just to the left of the muse handing the laurel bough to Hesiod. The muse on the right faces right and slightly forward. She looks forward and to the right, her face shown in three-quarters profile. The fingers of her right hand are visible on the shoulder of the muse standing to the left. A cithara or lyre is half-visible to the right of the muse's skirt near where her knee would be; just above and behind her harp is another shape that may be her left hand, holding the cithara. She is wearing a loosely-belted gown and a cloak over her upper body. Her hair is drawn back behind her head, and her head is bent forward. The toes of her right foot atop a sandal appear beneath the hem of her gown. This might be Erato, the muse of lyric poetry whose emblem is a cithara, or Terpsichore, the muse of dance whose emblem is a lyre.

A muse sits facing right and seen in profile at the left side of the design. This muse sits leaning forward and slightly hunched, holding a scepter or staff in both hands and with a cithara behind it. Her right arm is bent and held slightly forward, her forearm stretched out nearly horizontally. Her visible right leg is bent and her right foot rests flat on the floor. She is wearing a skirt that falls to the floor and covers half of her right foot. Over this skirt she wears a gown or long tunic that falls down from her shoulder to cover much of her right arm and is belted at the waist. Her hair, which must be long, is arranged in an elaborate coiffure, including one or two buns. This might be Erato, the muse of lyric poetry whose emblem is the cithara.

Above the cithara sits a muse with her lower body facing left. She twists to turn her torso forward and her head to the right so that her face is shown in profile. Her head is slightly bent, and her hair drawn back into a bun at the back of her head. A curl of hair appears above her forehead. Her right arm is bent at her side and her forearm lies on her lap. Her right hand is holding an open book that is also resting on her lap. Her left arm is bent and her elbow may be resting on a hidden support. Her forearm is bent upward and her left hand is at her chin, which may be resting on this hand. Her legs are bent and her feet are hidden behind another muse. She is wearing a sleeveless gown and has a cloak or other cloth draped over her lower right arm. This might be Calliope, the muse of epic poetry whose emblem is a writing tablet.

In the upper left corner a muse kneels at the feet of her sister, leaning on her lap. Her lower body faces left, but she twists her torso forward and to the right. Her right arm is at her side, bent upward, and her right hand is in a fist resting on her sister's knee. Her left arm is bent and raised so that her forearm rests horizontally along her sister's thigh. She holds her right wrist with her left hand. Her legs are bent and tucked underneath her. Her head is bent and the braid or twist over her right ear suggests that her hair is long and pulled back behind her head. She is wearing a long gown with buttons on the right shoulder.

In the upper left corner a muse faces left and sits leaning on a sculpted bust of Zeus, the father of all nine of the muses. The bust is probably made of marble. Her lower body faces left and slightly forward, but she turns her head to look forward and to the right. Her legs are bent, her lower legs and feet not pictured, and the bust of Zeus rests on her lap. The bust, with a beard and long hair, faces forward and to the left. It may be wearing a helmet or some other form of hat. The muse's left arm is at her side, bent upward, and her left hand rests on the top of the bust. She is wearing a sleeveless gown. Her hair is drawn back behind her ears and held with a headband. Braids or curls hang down on either side of her face.

lg.l: A ROD OF MARVELOUS GROWTH A LAUREL BOUGH
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: There are two preliminary drawings, one with variant sketches of the five muses, in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five muses play or sing for Jupiter (Zeus to the Greeks), their father, who is represented with long hair and a beard and covered with a cloak or other cloth draped over his lower body. Jupiter sits on the throne at the far right side of the design, facing forward and to the left. He rests his right foot on a decorative footstool, and leans forward to rest his chin on his right hand, with his right elbow propped on the arm of his throne. He holds at least three stylized lightning bolts, represented as rods with tapered ends, in the crook of his left elbow. The muses sit in a row across the bottom of the design, two near the middle facing away from the viewer and holding a lyre (left) and a cithara (right). Two other muses face forward and to the right: one of these holds rods or staves and the other plays a cithara or lyre(?), seen from the side, that rests on her lap. The fifth muse, sitting next to Jupiter's throne and facing left, holds her mouth open as if she is singing. All of the muses are dressed in long gowns of various styles and have their hair drawn back behind their heads.

component.illusobjdesc: Jupiter (Zeus to the Greeks), father of the muses at his feet, sits on his throne at the far right side of the design. The throne faces forward, but Jupiter turns diagonally left so that his body faces forward and left. He turns his head even further to the left, so that his face is seen in profile. Both of his legs are bent, and his right foot rests on a footstool, which lifts his right knee higher than his left. His right arm is bent upward at his side, elbow resting on his right knee and right hand at his chin with the first two fingers extended. He leans forward and to the left to rest his chin on this hand, his head down. His left arm is bent, elbow out from his body, and his forearm is resting along the arm of his throne. At least three stylized lightning bolts, depicted as long rods with tapered ends, are propped in the crook of his left elbow with their ends resting in his lap. He grasps them with his left hand, holding them between forefinger and the rest of his fingers. He wears a band around his head and a cloak or other cloth draped over his lap and wrapped around his left forearm, from where it falls in folds of drapery to the floor. His feet are encased in thong sandals with ankle straps. He is nude from the waist up, and has long semi-curly hair and a beard, which is partially hidden by his hand.

Jupiter sits on a throne, decorated with pine cone finials, at the far right side of the design, resting his right foot on a decorative footstool. The throne faces forward and is adorned with carved finials on either side of the backrest. The footstool is a low rectangular shape ornamented with scrollwork.

A muse sits on the floor facing left, just to the left of Jupiter's feet. She faces partly forward, so that her face and body are seen in partial profile. She is kneeling with legs bent underneath her. Her left arm is bent and at her side, her forearm resting along her lap. Her right hand is shown on her lap as well, emerging from the folds of a cloak or cloth that wraps her right forearm and falls to the floor. Her head is tilted slightly back, eyes raised, and her mouth is open as if she is singing. This might be Euterpe, the muse of music. She is wearing a sleeveless gown, gathered and belted or tied at the waist, and her hair is drawn back into a ponytail. She may be wearing a head band or other hair ornament, visible above and behind her left ear.

The muse fourth from the left sits facing forward and slightly left, though she turns her bent head sharply right. Both legs are bent at the knee and drawn in towards her body, crossed, but her right leg lies on the ground while her left knee is raised and her left foot, partially visible beneath the hem of her gown, rests flat on the floor. A musical instrument seen from the side, possibly a lyre or cithara, lies on her lap, resting on her lowered right leg and propped against her raised left knee. Her left arm is bent upward at her side and she holds the neck of the instrument with her left hand. Her right arm is bent at her side, and her forearm rests on the body of the instrument; the fingers of her right hand are raised as if she is playing it. She is wearing a long gown that may be gathered and belted or tied at the waist, and her hair is drawn back into a bun.

The muse third from left sits facing away from the viewer, with her body turned slightly left; she twists her head even further left, so that her face is seen in profile. Her head is bent down. Her visible left leg is bent and resting on the floor so that her left foot, emerging from the folds of her gown, is next to her buttocks. Her bent right arm is down and drawn back slightly, and she rests her right hand on the knee of the muse to her right. Her left arm is down and slightly bent, and her left hand may be resting on her lap. She loosely holds an arrow-like or dart-like object with the extended fingers of this hand. Her hair is drawn back into a bun, and an elaborate decorative net covers the bun and much of her head. She is wearing a long backless gown, belted at the waist, with a left shoulder strap that seems to have fallen down to rest over her upper left arm. Its skirts puddle on the floor behind her. A large cithara sits before her (partly hidden by her body), and a strap circling her back from right shoulder to below her left arm attaches her to the instrument. This might be Erato, the muse of lyric poetry whose emblem is the cithara.

The muse second from left sits facing away from the viewer and slightly to the right. She turns her head right so that her face is seen from behind in partial profile. She is sitting with her weight shifted onto her left hip, and the bottom of her left foot is visible beneath the folds of her clothing. Leaning leftward, she holds her bent left arm down and away from her body and props her left elbow on the thigh of the muse to the left, her hand dangling from the wrist. A large lyre is before her (partly hidden by her body). Her right arm is at her side, bent slightly upward, and she holds the right side of the instrument with her right hand. Her sister to the left plays the lyre with one hand. She is wearing a long gown, and may have a cloak or other cloth draped around her legs and lying on the floor behind her. Her hair is drawn back into a bun circled by a band, from which curly tendrils of hair escape. She or her companion to the left may be Terpsichore, the muse of dance whose emblem is the lyre.

The muse farthest left sits facing forward and to the right, but turns her head so that her face is seen in profile looking right. Her head is tilted back slightly. Both of her legs are bent and drawn up together, resting on the floor in front of her. She may be leaning away from the viewer slightly. Her left hand is visible on the other side of the muse to her right, where it rests on and perhaps plays the strings of the lyre that the muse second from right is holding. Her right arm is down at her side, slightly bent. A pair of staves are propped against the crook of this arm, leaning against her right shoulder; she rests her right hand with several fingers extended on (or perhaps holds) the staves near the base of their staffs. Her hair is drawn back into a bun at the crown of her head, from which several small curly tendrils escape. She is wearing a long gown, belted at the waist, which seems to be partly or entirely transparent since her legs and ankles are clearly visible through the fabric. Both feet emerge from the folds of this garment. She or her companion to the right may be Terpsichore, the muse of dance whose emblem is the lyre.

lg.l: THEY THE GREAT SPIRIT OF THEIR FATHER JOVE
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: There is a small ink preliminary sketch in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Winged Love, apparently a young male like Cupid, rises over the figures sprawled across the bottom of the design, which are (from left to right) Night, Erebus, and Chaos. He faces forward with his arms folded over his torso, hands on his breasts, and his large wings crossed over his pelvis. Beams of light surround him in a triangle shape. The rightmost figure lying below his feet is Chaos, who lies on his side facing left. He embraces his offspring Erebus (darkness), who is the middle figure, with his muscular right arm. Chaos' face seems to be cut off by the edge of the design, but his wild curly hair fills the lower right corner. Erebus, in the middle, lies face down with his head toward the viewer. Only his head and upper body are visible as he lies with his left arm bent under his chest and his right hand at his neck. His long curly hair spills from his head onto the ground around, and his face is hidden. The leftmost figure (Night) lies on his side facing right, wrapped in a cloak that obscures his entire head, face, and body except for his nose and chin, which are seen in profile facing right and down. Lines to the right of his lower body suggest shadow. Additional lines to the right of his upper body may represent shadow, or they may be hair from Erebus' head.

component.illusobjdesc: Winged Love, apparently a young male like Cupid, rises in a standing position over the figures sprawled across the bottom of the design. He faces forward and crosses his bent arms over his upper body, his right over his left. Each hand covers the opposite breast. His legs are straight, the left leg slightly forward. He holds his large wings folded near his body, and their longest primary feathers cross over his pelvis, hiding his genitals. His head is turned slightly to the right, and his curly chin-length hair is loose. Nude, he emits radiant beams of light forming a triangle shape around his body, its highest point above his head. Sketchy lines to the left of the leftmost figure sprawled below his feet may indicate additional beams of light.

Three figures sprawl across the bottom of the plate. The rightmost figure is Chaos, who is depicted upside down, lying on his side facing left. His head is nearest the bottom of the plate, while his feet are closest to Love. His visible right leg is bent and drawn in so that his foot is near his right buttock. He embraces his offspring Erebus, who lies to the left, with his muscular right arm, holding it slightly bent and extended out from his torso. Lines extending from the top of his shoulder to the bottom of the design suggest his throat and chin; his face seems to be cut off by the bottom of the design. His long curly hair masses wildly in the bottom right corner of the design, while additional hairs seem to spring from his chest. He may be nude or partly nude, though lines on his thigh suggest hair, scales, or some form of clothing. Sketchy lines to the right of his back may indicate the ground on which he lies.

Three figures sprawl across the bottom of the plate. The middle figure is Erebus (darkness), offspring of Chaos to the right. Lying face down, only his head and nude upper body are visible. His left arm is bent and lying on the ground, held in front of his body; he may be resting on this arm. His right hand is visible to the right of his head, between his head, neck, and shoulder, with the fingers bent. His long, curly hair spills from his head onto the ground around, and his face is hidden. His head is toward the viewer.

Three figures sprawl across the bottom of the design. The leftmost figure is Night, seen upside down lying on his side and facing right. He is wrapped in a cloak or other cloth that entirely covers his body except for his nose and chin, which are seen in profile facing right and down. The shape of his body beneath this cloak suggests that his right arm may be bent and wrapped around his body, and his legs may be bent. Lines to the right of his lower body suggest shadow. Additional lines to the right of his upper body may represent shadow, or they may be hair from Erebus' head. Similarly, diagonal lines to the left of Night's body may be shadow or they may be beams of light from Love.

lg.l: THEN LOVE MOST BEAUTEOUS OF IMMORTALS ROSE
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, Jan. 1 , 1817.

objnote.p: There are two pen and pencil preliminary drawings in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings. A proof of the engraving before all letters is in the Morgan Library and Museum, New York.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Waves of the sea cover the bottom of the design from one side to the other, "wafting" Venus to Cythera (see the engraved text below the design). They rise and fall in gently undulating swells that part to allow the dolphins and Triton to break their surface, although they support Venus' body entirely above water. She floats reclined, facing left but lying down nearly horizontally. She is nude and her long wavy hair hangs down her back. Her left arm lies along her body; her right hand (fingers spread) is raised to touch her chest or shoulder. The dolphin to her right is helping to support her back in her reclined position. This dolphin's coiled tail may be the spiral-like object rising above the waves near the right side of the design. Two putti help to escort Venus, carrying a large cloth that extends from one end of the design to the other, like a banner billowing in wind. The rightmost putto hovers or flies facing forward and to the left, with his arms spread wide to hold the right end of the banner or cloth. Unlike the other putto, he lacks visible wings. The putto on the left faces forward and to the right, but his body is tilted so that it aligns diagonally from upper right to lower left corner of the design. He holds the banner near its midpoint and in the middle of the loop it makes behind his back. He has feathered wings. Both putti are nude. The nude shoulders and arms of a Triton are shown near the lower left corner of the design: his arms are crossed and resting on the head of a second dolphin. His tail rises from the water to his right, just above Venus' legs; it curves upward and to the left, where it ends in upward pointing flukes over his left shoulder.

component.illusobjdesc: Venus (Aphrodite) reclines floating on the waves that bear her to Cythera (see the engraved text below the design), facing left but lying down nearly horizontally. Her legs are extended to the left but her knees are bent upwards, and her left leg is crossed over her right at the ankle. Her left arm is at her side, bent and lying on her lap. Her right forearm is visible bent upwards in front of her breast; her right hand is positioned just below her chin, palm facing in and down, and the slightly spread fingers of this hand may be resting on her shoulder. One breast is visible to the left of her left arm. Her head is bent slightly so that her face looks down, and her long wavy hair hangs down her back. She is nude, and her entire body is above water. The dolphin to her right is helping to support her back in her reclined position.

Two putti help to escort Venus as the waves bear her to Cythera. The rightmost putto hovers or flies facing forward and to the left, with his arms spread wide holding one end of the cloth the putti bear together. His left arm is slightly bent and extended nearly horizontally, and he grasps the lower edge of the cloth with this hand. His right arm is hidden by the folds of fabric, but a pucker in the cloth to the left of his head suggests his handhold. He tilts his head back to look up and to the left, and his mouth is open slightly. His legs are spread wide: his right leg is bent and drawn up so that his right foot touches his buttock, and his left leg is extended behind him. He has short hair, but unlike the other putto, he lacks visible wings. He is nude, and his genitals are visible. The cloth flies behind him and its right end flaps to his right.

Two putti help to escort Venus as the waves bear her to Cythera. The leftmost putto hovers or flies above Venus' legs, with his bent arms spread wide over his head to hold the cloth the putti bear together. He faces forward and to the right, but his body is tilted so that it aligns diagonally from upper right to lower left corner of the design. His right arm is raised nearly vertically, and he holds the cloth or banner near its midpoint with this hand. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees, and with this hand he grasps the cloth in the middle of the loop it makes to his right. His head is turned slightly to look forward. His right leg is extended and his left leg is bent and drawn back behind him. He is nude, and has feathered wings and short hair. The cloth crosses over itself to form a loop behind him, and its left end flutters to his left.

Two putti help to escort Venus. They bear a large cloth that extends from one end of the design to the other, like a banner. Its left end flutters near the top left corner of the plate. From there it dips to the right, where it makes a loop behind the leftmost putto, crossing over itself to the left and then billowing up towards the top of the plate. It descends to the right of Venus' head and crosses behind the rightmost putto's back. Its right end flaps to the right of this rightmost putto.

A Triton, near the lower left corner of the design, helps to escort Venus. His nude shoulders and upper body face forward, though his right shoulder is lower than the left. He turns his head forward and to the right. His arms are folded and crossed in front of his chest, right hand over left forearm, and they rest on the head of a dolphin that helps to support him above the waves. His tail rises from the water to his right, just above Venus' legs; it curves upward and to the left, where it ends in upward pointing flukes over his left shoulder.

Two dolphins help to escort Venus. The head of the one on the left peeks over the waves, supporting the Triton, who leans his crossed arms on it. Its eye is just visible over the waves, facing forward and to the right. The dolphin to the right supports Venus' back, and perhaps helps to propel her. Its head, with one eye pictured, appears above the waves to the right of Venus. Its coiled tail may be the spiral-like object rising above the waves just behind the rightmost putto.

Waves cover the bottom of the design from one side to the other, "wafting" Venus to Cythera (see the engraved text below the design). They rise and fall in gently undulating swells that part to allow the dolphins and the Triton to break their surface, although they support Venus' body entirely above water.

lg.l: FIRST BORE HER TO CYTHERA'S HEAVENLY COAST
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: There are two leaves of preliminary drawings and a proof of the engraving before all letters in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The sea covers the bottom of the design, swirling around both Tritons and rising in a wave to support Venus (Aphrodite) in the middle, whose body is entirely out of the water. She kneels facing forward but tilting her head back slightly and turning it to look up and to the right. Her right leg is bent and she rests on this knee, while her left leg is bent with the knee drawn up and her left foot flat on the wave. Her arms are bent and crossed over her torso. Two Tritons welcome her. The one to the right emerges from the water turned to the left and slightly away from the viewer, with his left arm bent and held slightly away and forward. His tail breaks the water to the right, curling away from the viewer before ending in flukes pointing up and to the left. The upper body of the one to the left emerges from the water bent forward towards the right. He extends both arms out horizontally towards Venus' feet, bending his head back to look up to the right. His tail rises from the water to the left, coiling up and back down into the water before emerging again at the left side of the design. Two putti also escort Venus. The one to the left flies or hovers facing right, with both arms extended out horizontally towards Venus. His legs are bent and drawn up behind him. The putto to the right flies or hovers facing left and holds both arms out roughly horizontally towards Venus. His slightly bent left leg is extended, and his lower right leg is visible, bent back and drawn up slightly, to the right of his upper left thigh. Both putti are nude with short hair, and have feathered wings. Light, wavy lines left and right of Venus, extending to the left margin on the left, suggest the "foam" bearing her (see the engraved words below the image). Curving lines upper right may be more foam or even a rainbow.

component.illusobjdesc: Venus kneels on a wave, facing forward but turning her head to look up and to the right so that her face is seen in profile. She bends her head back slightly. Her right leg is bent and she rests on her knee; the toes of her right foot are visible to the left of her knee. Her left leg is bent with her knee drawn up and her left foot flat on the wave. Her arms are bent and crossed over her torso, right forearm over left forearm, so that the crook of each elbow cradles a breast; her hands are open with the palms resting flat on her chest. Her long hair is loose with curls above her forehead and a lock falling over each shoulder. She is nude. Although she is floating on a wave, her body is entirely out of the water.

Two Tritons welcome Venus. The upper body of the one on the right emerges from the water turned to the left and slightly away from the viewer, so that his face is shown in quarter profile. His head seems to be bent back slightly. His left arm is bent and held slightly forward away from his side, with his left palm up and facing forward and in. His open right hand is visible to the left of his right shoulder. His tail breaks the water to the right, twisting up to the left, down to the right, and up again before ending in flukes pointing up and to the left. He is nude and has short hair.

Two Tritons welcome Venus. The upper body of the one to the left emerges from the water bent forward towards the right. He extends both arms out horizontally towards Venus' feet, with his hands open, fingers together and thumb raised, and palms facing in towards each other. He bends his head back to look up to the right. He has short hair and is nude, with a noticeably large and pointed ear. His tail rises from the water to the left, coiling up to the right and down to the left before re-entering the water, emerging again above at the left side of the design. From there it curls up and then down to the right, before ending in flukes pointing up.

Two putti escort Venus. The one to the left hovers or flies just to the left of Venus, facing right but with his body positioned on a diagonal from upper right to lower left corner of the design. He extends both arms out horizontally towards Venus; his left arm is straight and his right is slightly bent. Both hands are open, with his right palm vertical and his left facing slightly up. His legs are bent and drawn up behind him, his right slightly more than his left. He is nude and his genitals are visible. He has short hair and feathered wings.

Two putti escort Venus. The putto to the right hovers or flies just to the right of Venus, facing left but with his body positioned on a diagonal from upper left to lower right corner of the design. Like a mirror image of his fellow putto, he extends both arms out roughly horizontally torwards Venus; his right arm is straight and his left is slightly bent. Both hands are open with the palms vertical, though his right may also face up slightly. His slightly bent left leg is extended, and his lower right leg is visible, bent back and drawn up slightly, to the right of his upper left thigh. He is nude, and has short hair and feathered wings.

The sea covers the bottom of the design from one side to the other, swirling around both Tritons and rising in a wave to support Venus, whose body is entirely out of the water. Light, wavy lines left and right of Venus, extending to the left margin on the left, suggest the cloud-like "foam" bearing her (see the engraved words below the image). Arching lines upper right may be more foam or even a rainbow.

lg.l: HER APHRODITE GODS AND MORTALS NAME
Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London, November 1, 1816.

objnote.p: There is a pen and pencil preliminary drawing, and another leaf bearing two small preliminary sketches, in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Venus (Aphrodite) stands near the middle of the design presenting a winged, Cupid-like personification of love to Zeus and Hera. Nude except for a cloak or cloth that wraps around her lower body, she stands facing left with her visible left leg bent slightly forward and her left foot on tiptoe. Her arms are at her side, with her left hand holding his left hand. The child stands or hovers with at least one foot resting on tiptoe in Venus' right palm, which is visible to the left of her pelvis. He leans forward slightly and extends his bent right arm; this hand is held in the fingers of Zeus's own had. The child is nude and has visible genitals, short hair, and feathered wings. Zeus stands to the left of Venus, facing right and slightly away from the viewer. He is dressed in a large cloak that drapes over his right shoulder and arm and hides much of his body. He stands with his feet wide apart and holds his right hand up to hold the hand of the winged personification of love. His left arm is bent and drawn back behind him, and he holds a staff or rod with this hand. He has long hair and his head is circled by a thin band. Hera stands to his left at the left side of the design, facing right and wearing her royal finery, which includes a belted gown, a tasseled and decorated cloak, and a tiara or crown possibly surmounted with gems or pearls. Her right forearm is bent up and her right hand rests in the crook of Zeus's left elbow. His staff may be partly resting against her arm. The three Graces stand embracing one another in their traditional circular arrangement near the right side of the design. One, standing in the middle, faces away from the viewer but turns her head to look left. The Grace to her right faces forward but turns her head down and to the left. The third Grace, to the right, looks forward and to the left. All three Graces are nude from the waist up, and draped in cloaks or other cloths from the waist down, with their hair in buns. Three zodiacal constellations (left to right, Gemini, Leo, and Virgo) and other stars indicate the heavenly setting. Gemini is represented as a dotted line outline of two heads in the lower left corner. Virgo appears near the upper right corner as the dotted line outline of the head and upraised arms of a woman. The dotted line outline of a lion's paw and head facing left with mouth open, representing Leo, is visible to the left of Venus' legs. Additional stars help to increase the impression of the heavenly setting.

component.illusobjdesc: The three Graces stand embracing one another in their traditional circular arrangement near the right side of the design. One, in the middle, stands facing away from the viewer, but looking left so that her face is seen in profile from behind. Her right arm is bent and raised so that she can rest her right hand on the shoulder of another Grace standing before her and to the right. She holds her left arm slightly out from her side, bent with forearm extended horizontally; her left hand rests on the hip of the Grace standing before her and to the left. She is nude from the waist up, with a cloak or cloth draped around her waist and hiding her lower body entirely except for her lower right leg, which is visible from the knee down with her right foot on tiptoe. This cloth also wraps around her left arm and falls in folds of drapery towards the floor on her right after it circles her waist. Her hair is drawn back into a bun. The Grace to the left faces forward in contrapposto, though she turns her head down and to the left so that her face is seen in profile. She holds her right arm bent upward and held forward so that her right hand can rest on the shoulder of the Grace to the right. This arm may be resting on the left arm of the middle Grace. Her lower body is entirely swathed in cloth, but the folds of the drapery suggest that her weight is on her right leg, with her left knee bent forward. She is nude from the waist up and her right breast is outlined. Her hair is drawn back into a bun at the crown of her head. The third Grace, farthest right, is visible mostly as a head and arm, though the bottom of her skirts appear to the right of the middle Grace's right leg. She holds her left arm bent and out from her side, embracing the middle Grace with her hand resting on this Grace's buttocks. Her head is turned to look forward and slightly left, and her hair seems to be drawn up into a bun or similar coiffure above the crown of her head. Folds of drapery just below her elbow suggest that, like her sisters, she is nude from the waist up.

Hera stands at the left side of the design, facing right in profile and wearing her royal finery. She is dressed in a gown that is belted at the waist and has a decorative hem. Over this she wears a cloak draped over her right shoulder and forearm; it too has a decorative hem as well as three tassels and an embroidered design in the lowest visible corner. Her hair seems to be drawn back to the nape of her neck, and a tiara or crown, possibly decorated with gems or pearls along its upper edge, surmounts her head. The toes of her right foot, clad in a sandal, are visible beneath the hem of her gown. Her right forearm is bent up and her right hand rests in the crook of Zeus's elbow. Zeus's staff may be partly resting against her arm.

Zeus stands near the left side of the design, just to the right of Hera, facing forward and slightly away from the viewer. He is dressed in a large cloak with a decorative hem that drapes over his right shoulder and arm and hides much of his body. His legs, visible from mid-calf down, are spread with feet spaced widely apart. His right hand is visible bent upward and held out to hold with his fingers the hand of the winged personification of love that Venus is presenting to him. His left arm is bent and drawn back behind him. He holds a staff or rod with this hand; the staff may also be partially propped against Hera's arm as she rests her hand in the crook of Zeus's left elbow. He has long hair, and a thin band circles his head. He is wearing sandals, and may be nude except for the cloak.

Venus (Aphrodite) stands near the middle of the design, facing left and presenting a winged, Cupid-like personification of love to Zeus and Hera. She stands with her visible left leg bent slightly forward and her left foot on tiptoe. Her left arm is at her side, forearm bent upward and left hand holding the hand of the winged personification. This winged child stands or hovers with at least one foot resting on tiptoe in Venus' right palm, which is visible to the left of her pelvis. Her bent right elbow is shown to the right of the small of her back. She bends her head slightly, and her hair is drawn back into a bun. Her upper body is nude, but her lower body is covered by a cloth that wraps around her waist and seems to drape over her right arm and hand, from where it falls in folds to the floor, parting to reveal her left foot. It may be semi-transparent. The child stands or hovers with his left leg down and his right leg bent and drawn back slightly. He leans forward slightly and extends his bent right arm; this hand is held in the fingers of Zeus's own right hand. His bent left arm is down and this hand is in Venus'. He is nude and has visible genitals, short hair, and feathered wings.

Three zodiacal constellations (left to right, Gemini, Leo, and Virgo) and other stars indicate the heavenly setting. Gemini is represented by five stars within a dotted line outline of two heads positioned in the lower left corner. Virgo appears near the upper right corner as the dotted line outline of the head of a woman with her arms raised at 135 degrees. Six stars twinkle within the outline, with five others in an arch to the right. Dotted lines to the left and right of the leftmost Grace below may represent the continuation of this constellation, as may the dotted lines and two stars near the lower right corner of the design. The dotted line outline of a lion's paw and head facing left with its mouth open, teeth visible, and tongue extended, representing Leo, is visible to the left of Venus' legs. Additional stars above Leo help to increase the impression of a heavenly setting.

objnote.p: There are three leaves of preliminary pen and pencil sketches in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings. illustration.illusobjdesc:
Two dolphins and ten of the fifty Nereids disport in the ocean on either side of Nereus and Doris, who embrace at the center. Doris (mother of the Nereids) faces left, her right arm twisted gently behind her back and her tail coiling up out of the water and to the left. She leans forward slightly, into Nereus, and her mouth is open. Her long hair is loose and down. Nereus faces forward, with his bent right arm out slightly form his side and his forearm lying on a coil of his tail. An oar is propped against his tail and right shoulder. He turns his head to the right, bending it slightly. His tail coils up out of the water in front of him, bending left before ending in another upward coil. Another segment of it appears to the left of his lower torso. He has a long beard and long hair, surmounted by a horned ornament above his forehead. Two Nereids embrace to the left of Nereus, one facing away and reclined rightwards, floating on top of the water, the other facing forward and visible from the shoulders up. A Nereid sits facing right at the left edge of the design. Her head is down and she may be reclining slightly. She may have her left elbow propped on a wave behind her back; she holds her bent right arm slightly extended and grasps the end of a cloth that flies like a banner over her head with this hand. The Nereid to the right reclines facing forward and to the left, sitting on top of the waves with her bent legs extended to the left and slightly forward. They are propped on a dolphin whose head breaks the waves beneath her knees. She is leaning back with her head bent slightly forward. Her left hand rests on the shoulder of the Nereid to the right, and her slightly bent right arm is extended horizontally to the left. With her left hand she holds one end of the same cloth or banner. Another Nereid is visible just to the left of Nereus' right shoulder, facing forward with her head turned to the right and away. She holds her right arm out to the left, her hand holding part of another cloth that flies over the Nereids. Her right hand, visible just to the left of Nereus' shoulder, holds another section of the cloth. Two more Nereids cavort just to the right of Doris. The one in front faces forward, reclining on her right side with her left leg lying mostly above the waves to the right. She curls her torso upward and lifts her left arm up to the right, turning her head to look right. The fingers of her right hand are shown holding Doris' forearm. Above and to the left of her, another Nereid faces forward, turning her bent head to the right. She spreads her arms wide, and her left hand is visible holding another section of banner. At the right side of the design, three Nereids disport together. The foremost one, half-submerged, faces away but turns her head left, her arms wide and her left hand holding part of a fourth banner. To the right, the middle nymph sits or kneels, floating, with her legs bent and drawn up out of the water. Although her legs face right, she turns her torso away and twists her head even further to look away and to the left. She embraces the third Nereid with her bent right arm and raises her left forearm at 135 degrees, holding part of the banner with several fingers of this hand. The third Nereid, farthest away from the viewer and nearest the right edge of the design, is shown from the breasts up facing forward. She turns her head to the left and extends her right arm at 135 degrees, with her hand raised palm down, touching the banner-like cloth. Her left forearm is bent upward at her side and her left hand rests on and perhaps holds the right forearm of the middle Nereid in this cluster of three. All of the Nereids are nude except for folds of cloth that drape over their lower bodies, when visible, and merge with the water on which they float or in which they are partially submerged. All of them have hair drawn back into buns except for the Nereid second to left and fifth from right, both of which may have short hair or hair drawn back into a bun.
Two dolphins appear in the waves with the Nereids. The head of one breaks the water to the right of Doris, its eye and snout visible above the surface facing left. The head of the other emerges near the left side of the design, propping up the legs of a reclining Nereid, eye and snout facing left. The Nereids hold cloths that fly above their heads like banners. One curves over the head of a Nereid at the left side of the design. Another extends from the Nereid second to left to just over Doris' head. A third flies above the two Nereids to the right of Doris, and a fourth over the three Nereids at the right side of the design. The sea covers the bottom of the design from one side to the other, swirling around both all the Nereids and merging with the folds of fabric that often drape over their lower bodies when visible. It supports the nymphs who emerge from or float on its surface in various positions, forming little waves, especially to the left of the leftmost Nereid and around the bodies of Nereus and Doris.

component.illusobjdesc: At the center of the design, Nereus embraces Doris, the mother of the Nereids. Her slightly bent right arm is extended horizontally to the left, and she holds one end of the cloth that flies in the air like a banner over the leftmost Nereid in this hand. She is nude except for the folds of cloth that drape over her legs, leaving her feet uncovered, and seem to merge with the waves below her. Her breasts are visible. Her hair is curled over her ears and may be short or may be drawn back behind her head.

A Nereid just to the left of Nereus' right shoulder is visible from the breast up, facing forward with her head turned to the right and away so that her face is visible only in partial profile. She holds her right arm out to the left, her forearm bent upward and her hand holding part of the cloth that flies over the Nereids like a banner. Her right hand is visible just to the left of Nereus' shoulder, in front of her own shoulder, holding another section of the cloth. She may be leaning back slightly. Her hair is drawn back into a bun, and her visible body is nude; the partial outline of both breasts is visible.

Two nymphs cavort just to the right of Nereus and Doris. The one in the front faces forward but turns her head to the right; her head may also be bent back slightly. She is reclining on her right side, with at least her left leg lying mostly above the waves to the right, slightly bent. She curls her torso upward and lifts her left arm up to the right, bent upward and open hand raised with the palm down. She may be touching the cloth that flies over the Nereids' heads like a banner. Her visible right forearm suggests that her right arm is held out from her body. The fingers of her right hand are shown holding Doris' forearm. She is nude except for the fold of cloth that drapes over her left thigh and covers her foot and part of her lower left leg, seeming to merge with the waves on which she floats. Her breasts are visible and her hair is drawn back into a bun. Above and slightly to the left of her, the upper body of another Nereid is visible. She faces forward, but turns her bent head to the right, so that her face is shown in profile looking down. Her forearm, extended horizontally leftward, is all that is visible of her right arm. Her left forearm is also extended nearly horizontally, and several fingers of her right hand hold a portion of the cloth that flies over her head like a banner. She appears nude, and the curves of her breasts are just visible between Doris and the other Nereid. Her hair is curled over her ears and may be short or may be pulled back behind her head.

Three Nereids disport together at the right side of the design. The foremost one is half-submerged in the water and visible only from the waist up; she may be swimming or floating. She faces away but turns her head to the left so that her face is shown in profile. Her bent right arm is down and extended to her right; she may be embracing the legs of the nymph to the right with this arm. Her left arm is raised horizontally, forearm bent upwards. The fingers of her left hand are visible above the shoulder of the nymph to the left, and may be grasping part of the cloth that flies over the three Nereids' heads like a banner. To the right, partially hidden by this foremost nymph, is another who kneels or sits, floating, with her legs bent and drawn up out of the water. Although her legs face right, she turns her torso away from the viewer, and twists her head even further to look away and to the left. She holds her bent right arm out to embrace the third Nereid, behind her and to the right. Her right hand rests on this third nymph's left shoulder. Her forearm is visible raised at 135 degrees to the left, and she holds part of the same bannerlike cloth with several fingers of this hand. The third Nereid, farthest away from the viewer and nearest the right edge of the design, is shown from the breasts up facing forward. She turns her head to the left and extends her right arm at 135 degrees, with her hand extended palm down, touching the bannerlike cloth. Her left forearm is bent upward at her side and her left hand rests on and perhaps holds the right forearm of the middle nymph. All three nymphs are nude, with hair swept up into buns.

Two dolphins appear in the waves with the Nereids. The head of one breaks the water to the right of Doris, its eye and snout visible above the surface facing left. The head of the other emerges near the left side of the design, propping up the legs of a reclining Nereid, eye and snout facing left.

The Nereids hold cloths that fly above their heads like banners. One curves over the head of a Nereid at the left side of the design. Another extends from the Nereid second to left to just over Doris' head. A third flies above the two Nereids to the right of Doris, and a fourth over the three Nereids at the right side of the design.

The sea covers the bottom of the design from one side to the other, swirling around both all the Nereids and merging with the folds of fabric that often drape over their lower bodies when visible. It supports the nymphs who emerge from or float on its surface in various positions, forming little waves especially to the left of the leftmost Nereid and around the bodies of Nereus and Doris.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Echidna, half-woman and half-serpent, receives the attention of Typhon (left). Her monster offspring flesh out the scene: the Sphinx (left), the triple-headed Geryon, the Chimera with its two heads (lion and goat), and the Hydra. Echidna is positioned near the center of the design, facing forward and slightly left, though she turns her head slightly to the right. She holds her bent right arm out horizontally to the left, and Typhon holds her right hand. Her left hand is grasped in Geryon's hand, to the right. She is nude and has long hair, and a headpiece consisting of two ornamental serpents appears above her forehead. Her serpent lower body curves into three large coils near the bottom of the design. Typhon's body, to the left, leans leftward although his torso is twisted slightly forward and his head is turned to the right. He holds his bent right arm extended across his body, hand raised and holding Echidna's right hand. The fingers of his right hand are visible resting against Echidna's right hip and waist. His relatively long hair flies loosely on either side of his head, surmounted by two wings above his forehead. He is nude. Lines that rise from his lower torso diagonally leftward before curving to the left and down may be intended to represent wind or a banner-like cloth. The Sphinx sits near the left side of the design. Her lion's body faces left, while her human head turns to look right, her face seen in three-quarters profile. Her feathered wings are raised and folded behind her back. Her body is covered in fur and she has claws on each foot. Two or three breasts are visible beneath her abdomen. Triple-headed Geryon lunges left, just to the right of Echidna. Alternatively, he may be seated on the back of the Chimera, below him. His muscled right leg is bent and drawn forward, his foot on tiptoe, while his muscled left leg is extended behind him, knee facing forward and foot on tiptoe. His lower body faces forward and to the left, but he twists his torso so that his chest and all three heads look left. He holds his bent left arm at his side, and he grasps Echidna's left hand with this hand. Each head wears a helmet, and both the heads with visible faces have beards. He wears an armored breastplate over a short tunic. The Chimera, with the body of a lion and two heads, one of a lion and one of a goat, crouches or lies near the bottom of the design at the right, facing left. The lion head, encircled by a mane, also rests on the ground with mouth open and one tooth visible. Flames or hot wind blast from the lion head's open mouth. The goat head appears above the lion's head, with horns and a tuft of "beard." The Chimera's tail spirals in corkscrews behind it, nearer to the right edge of the design. The Hydra coils near the right side of the design, its body rising from the ground in at least three large coils. Five snake heads are visible, each facing right with mouth open and breathing fire or clouds of smoke. The forked tongue of the lowest head is also extended.

component.illusobjdesc: The Sphinx sits near the left side of the design. Her lion's body faces left, while her human head turns to look right, her face seen in three-quarters profile. She has relatively short, curly hair on her head. Her feathered wings are raised and folded behind her back. She sits with her left hind leg drawn in and her right hind leg extended. Her left foreleg ("arm") is down, resting on a rock or small mound, while her right foreleg ("arm") is raised nearly vertically. Her body is covered in fur and she has claws on each foot. Two or three breasts are visible beneath her abdomen.
The Sphinx rests her left front paw on a rock or small mound of earth.

Typhon appears to the left of Echidna, who is positioned near the middle of the plate. His body leans leftward although his torso is twisted slightly forward and his head is turned to the right so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. He holds his bent right arm extended across his body, hand raised and holding Echidna's right hand. His upper left arm is drawn back, and his right fingers are visible resting against Echidna's right hip and waist. His relatively long hair flies loosely on either side of his head, surmounted by two wings above his forehead. He is nude. Lines that rise from his lower torso diagonally leftward before curving to the left and down may be intended to represent wind or a banner-like cloth.

Echidna is positioned near the center of the design, facing forward and slightly to the left, though she turns her head slightly to the right. She holds her bent right arm out horizontally to the left, and Typhon holds her right hand. Her visible upper left arm is out slightly from her side, and her left hand is grasped in Geryon's left hand. She is nude with visible breasts, and her hair is long and down. A headpiece consisting of two ornamental serpents appears above her forehead. Her serpent lower body curves into three large coils near the bottom of the design. She is the mother of the monsters surrounding her.

Triple-headed Geryon lunges left, just to the right of Echidna. Alternatively, he may be seated on the back of the Chimera, below him. His muscled right leg is bent and drawn forward, his foot on tiptoe, while his muscled left leg is extended behind him, knee facing forward and foot on tiptoe. His lower body faces forward and to the left, but he twists his torso so that his chest and all three heads look left. All three heads are also bent back slightly. He holds his bent left arm at his side, and he grasps Echidna's left hand with this hand. Each head wears a helmet, and both the heads with visible faces have beards. He wears an armored breastplate over a short tunic.

The Chimera, with the body of a lion and two heads, one of a lion and one of a goat, crouches or lies near the bottom of the design at the right, facing left. Both visible legs, each with a large lion paw, lie along the ground. The lion head, encircled by a mane, also rests on the ground with mouth open and one tooth visible. Flames or hot wind blast from the lion head's open mouth. The goat head appears above the lion's head, with horns and a tuft of "beard." The Chimera's tail spirals in corkscrews behind it, nearer to the right edge of the design.

The Hydra coils near the right side of the design, its body rising from the ground in at least three large coils. Five snake heads are visible, each facing right with mouth open and breathing fire or clouds of smoke. The forked tongue of the lowest head is also extended.
